Article: When Philippe Zdar tragically passed away last night, at the age of 52, the disco-kissed French touch style of house music that flourished in Parisian nightclubs in the 1990s lost one of its chief architects and most talented craftsmen. Born Philippe Cerboneschi, the son of a hotelier in the French Alps, Zdar got his start in the music business on its very lowest rung, as a â€œtea boyâ€ at Parisâ€™ Studio Marcadet, where he was kept around, he once said, because he made good jokes and rolled good joints. His first year at the studio, Prince, Bryan Ferry, and Sade all recorded there. â€œIt took me a while to begin to understand stuff, and I still donâ€™t mind if I donâ€™t know what all the gear does,â€ he said last year. â€œIâ€™m happy to work as a craftsman who learned enough about the technical side to make what he wants.â€What distinguished Zdarâ€™s musicâ€”both in his own groups and as a Grammy-winning producer of artists including Phoenix and Cat Powerâ€”was that unusually tactile quality. In the early â€™90s, at the same time that Daft Punk were channeling Chicagoâ€™s raw, machinic house music into a fresh, filter-swept sound, Zdarâ€™s groups La Funk Mob (with Boom Bass, aka Hubert Blanc-Francard, the son of Zdarâ€™s first studio boss) and Motorbass (with Etienne de CrÃ©cy) invented their very own strain of loopy, funk-infused downbeat and house. Then, at the turn of the millennium, Zdar reunited with Blanc-Francard to form Cassius, who would perfect that gossamer, unmistakably French sound and tilt it toward pop.Over the years, Zdar translated his innate curiosity, attention to detail, technical acumen, and boundless intuition into one of the most sought-out signatures in contemporary music, working with everyone from Beastie Boys to the Rapture to Franz Ferdinand. (Most recently, he contributed to Hot Chipâ€™s new album, .) On some records heâ€™s credited as a mixer, on others as a producer, but Zdarâ€™s collaborators tended to describe his role in more nebulous terms, as a sort of alchemist, or midwife. This seemed to suit him. â€œThere are a few things in your body that you donâ€™t control, like swallowing, sweating, your heartbeat,â€ he told  in 2012, â€œthis is exactly how it feels for me producing. People call it â€˜producing,â€™ I call it â€˜helpingâ€™â€”itâ€™s the same. Itâ€™s totally natural.â€More than anything, in an industry characterized by its implacable egos and platinum-card swagger, Zdar was known for his humility. He was proud of the fact that he had poured his DJ earnings into building his Motorbass studio into a shrine to analog craft; he spent months in Ibiza every yearâ€”not to party but to spend time on a rural ranch. â€œI would also hope that the artists I work with are good people,â€ he said. â€œTo me, thatâ€™s more important than talent. If someone is an asshole, Iâ€™m not interested in going into the studio with them, even if their music is incredible. The way I spend my time nowadays is what matters the most to me.â€Here are nine of Zdarâ€™s most definitive productions.Zdar was still starting out when French rapper MC Solaar came calling, looking for someone to record his debut single. Hubert Blanc-Francard supplied the beats; Zdar mixed and engineered, using a Fairchild compressorâ€”a favorite of the Beatlesâ€”to put an idiosyncratic twist on the music, a world away from the rougher sound of American boom-bap. That sound would become a trademark of French rap. Daft Punkâ€™s Thomas Bangalter would later credit Zdarâ€™s compression as an influence on Daft Punkâ€™s own style.La Funk Mobâ€™s records on Mo Wax represented an early win for French dance music, at a time that UK clubbers werenâ€™t much interested in what was happening among their Gallic neighbors. Impressed with Blanc-Francardâ€™s beats for MC Solaar, M0 Wax label chief James Lavelle asked for more instrumentals in a similar vein, but not two- and three-minute cuts: He wanted longer excursions befitting the trip-hop labelâ€™s heady, psychedelic sound. Blanc-Francard reached out to Zdar, and the two endeavored to try making tracks similar to what Zdar was doing with Motorbassâ€”sleek, sculpted grooves, just one or two sampled loops polished like marbleâ€”but with the four-to-the-floor pulse replaced by broken beats. They also put their hands to drowsier, more downbeat cuts, like the unforgettably titled â€œRavers Suck Our Sound and Get Fuck,â€ while remixes from Carl Craig and Richie Hawtin carried their tunes into clubbier territory.It was with Etienne de CrÃ©cy that Zdar notched his firstâ€”and, to real house music heads, his most enduringâ€”classic album. Where the duoâ€™s two 1993 EPs are rougher, more exploratory affairs,  is less rowdy, more heads-down, driven by powerful, swollen bass frequencies that are more felt than heard. As opposed to the silky approach Daft Punk were taking at the time, Zdarâ€™s mixing dove directly into the goo, stirring up his sounds until they were as thick and disorienting as trucker coffee.The Source label was a key outlet for French electronic music in the â€™90s, and its 1995 compilation  gave many listeners their first taste of artists like Air, DJ Cam, Alex Gopher, and DJ Gilb-R. Zdarâ€™s productions turns up four times on that album. It fell to La Funk Mobâ€™s â€œSlimfasstâ€ to kick the whole thing off: an unorthodox take on drumâ€™nâ€™bass that proved exactly how freaky French electronic music could get.Most people remember Ã‰tienne de CrÃ©cyâ€™s  compilation for de CrÃ©cyâ€™s own â€œPrix Choc,â€ an easygoing jazzy house track with the looped refrain of â€œSensemillia/Marijuanaâ€ spoken in Jamaican patois over the top. But Zdar also teamed up with de CrÃ©cy under the one-off alias La Chatte Rouge for a string- and trumpet-laden downtempo track thatâ€™s as opulent as the furniture at Versailles.Cassiusâ€™  marked the end of an era. Awash in sumptuous funk and soul samples, buffed to a deep gleam, and less interested in pop musicâ€™s quick-hit dopamine bursts the dancefloorâ€™s hypnotic slow burn,  is really the last great example of the French touch. The ebullient Gwen McCrae-sampling single â€œFeeling for Youâ€ laid the groundwork for a strain of disco-sampling anthem that would yield results as different as DJ Kozeâ€™s â€œPick Upâ€ and Aviciiâ€™s â€œLevels.â€In 2000, Zdar worked with then-newcomers Phoenix to mix their debut album, . Guitarist Laurent Brancowitz credited him for rescuing the record from abject failure: â€œPhilippe came and he saved the album; he was a Christ-like figure, we were doomed and he saved us.â€ Itâ€™s not hard to hear Zdarâ€™s touch on songs like â€œToo Youngâ€ and â€œIf I Ever Feel Better,â€ which sparkle with an impossible-to-define sense of presence. That sense is heightened on 2009â€™s , where Brancowitz deemed Zdarâ€™s role as more akin to â€œcreative advisor.â€ The vividness with which he renders every sound, no matter how small or seemingly insignificant, elevates the album, highlighting the bandâ€™s quirks and brokering an oft-attempted, seldom-accomplished alliance between indie rock and disco. Itâ€™s a joyful, guileless soundâ€”a celebration of balance and proportion, an invitation to immerse yourself in a studio-constructed illusion.There was a time when it  would have been unthinkable to say Cat Powerâ€™s and Philippe Zdarâ€™s names in the same breath. Then he produced , her ninth album. Chan Marshallâ€™s best work has always been mostly sinew and bone, wrapping her voice around simple, declarative chord changes, and Zdar honors that formula while blowing it up into four dimensions. Multi-tracking, synthesizers, the odd breakbeat or drum machine, and once, even, the almost-hokey sample of an eagleâ€™s cryâ€”he brings it all in, subtly polishing her sound without ever losing sight of its essence.It is the very worst kind of irony that Cassiusâ€™ , the follow-up to their 2016 album , is out tomorrow. (Zdar was also billed to play Central Parkâ€™s Summerstage this Sunday.) A handful of singles from the album have appeared in the past few months, and the most recent, â€œCalliope,â€ is among the best things the duo has done in years. A world away from â€™s more over-the-top inclinations, â€œCalliopeâ€ looks back to classic â€™90s techno without ever feeling like an overt throwback. The song starts minimally with gaseous, dub-techno chords, but once the beat kicks in, the tune swiftly converts itself a kind of eyes-closed, deeply ecstatic deep house, the kind of thing that would sound sublime at sunriseâ€”whether on an outdoor dancefloor surrounded by a thousand loved-up ravers or sitting on the patio of a rural Ibizan finca, far from the madding crowd. Like all of Zdarâ€™s best work, itâ€™s a song that creates its own world.

Article: The Atlanta artist interpolates Nirvanaâ€™s â€œIn Bloomâ€ on the  cutLil Nas X has released a new song titled â€œPanini.â€ Itâ€™s from his forthcoming  EP, which is out tomorrow (Friday, June 21) via Columbia. On Apple Music, the song credits: Montero Lamar Hill (aka Lil Nas X), Denzel Baptiste and David Biral (aka producers Take A Daytrip), Oladipo Omishore (aka Dot da Genius), and Kurt Cobain. And people was like, â€˜.â€™ I was like, no. Itâ€™s like, I didnâ€™t realize I was using almost the exact same melody.â€Lil Nas Xâ€™s  opens with the Billy Ray Cyrus remix of his smash hit â€œOld Town Road.â€ The EP follows Lil Nas Xâ€™s self-released 2018 project NASARATI.Read â€œHow Lil Nas Xâ€™s â€˜Old Town Roadâ€™ Became a Lightning Rod for Race, the Charts, and Country Musicâ€ on the Pitch.Watch Lil Nas X on Pitchforkâ€™s â€œOver/Underâ€:

Hot Chip, the Black Madonna, Franz Fredinandâ€™s Alex Kapranos, and others pay tribute to the late producerPhilippe Zdarâ€”legendary producer, DJ, and one-half of French electronic duo Cassiusâ€”died yesterday at age 52. Since the news of his death broke, countless artists have taken to social media to pay homage to the late icon of French house music, including Cat Power, Chromeo, Hudson Mohawke, the Black Madonna, Savagesâ€™ Jehnny Beth, Hot Chip, Franz Fredinandâ€™s Alex Kapranos, Mark Ronson, Pedro Winter, and more. Phoenix posted an uncaptioned black square on Instagram. Find tributes below.In addition to releasing Cassius albums for the past 20 years alongside partner Hubert Blanc-Francard (aka Boom Bass), Zdar worked with a whoâ€™s-who of artists including Phoenix, Beastie Boys, Cat Power, Franz Ferdinand, Air, Chromeo, Bloc Party, and many others.

Article: Up until this month, King Crimson were among the final streaming-service holdouts from the classic rock era. And it made sense. Robert Fripp has famously stated that his pioneering prog outfit isnâ€™t simply a band but also a â€œway of doing things.â€ Often, that way of doing things involves resisting the obvious pathâ€”sometimes at the expense of the bandâ€™s stability. The past 50 years of Crimson have been defined by restlessness, thanks to an ever-changing lineup and a sound thatâ€™s always searching (typically in odd tunings and time signatures). In one song, theyâ€™re a gnarly rock trio with tritone riffs; in another, theyâ€™re a gorgeous folk outfit with flutes and fantastical lyrics. Combine that tendency with their myriad spin-off projects (referred to as ProjeKcts), collaborative releases, and absurdly elaborate box sets, and you have one of the more intimidating bodies of work in rock history. But now that the majority of their catalog has finally arrived on Spotify, Apple Music, and more, itâ€™s never been easier to join the Court of King Crimson. Start with these six albums, and explore the rest at your own pace.King Crimsonâ€™s debut album presents their most recognizable face. Itâ€™s there on the coverâ€”the iconic painting by Bary Godberâ€”but itâ€™s also in the restless, symphonic music. Songs like â€œ21st Century Schizoid Manâ€ and â€œThe Court of the Crimson Kingâ€ have lost none of their paranoid energy, and ballads like â€œI Talk to the Windâ€ and â€œMoonchildâ€ remain among their most memorable deep cuts. The defining sounds of the recordâ€”Ian McDonaldâ€™s Mellotron and the passionate vocals of Greg Lakeâ€”would soon be phased out, as Fripp began experimenting more. But it would take years for the rest of the world to catch up to the vision of .Stream it on: Spotify, Apple MusicIf you like this, consider listening to: King Crimsonâ€™s 1970 follow-up, . It essentially recreates the formula of this album, to varying degrees of success.The title is fitting: These jazzy, string-accompanied tracks are somewhat disconnected from King Crimsonâ€™s larger body of work, but theyâ€™re worth a visit. Their final album to feature the lyrics of Peter Sinfield,  is a transitional work, showing a band on the way to a tighter, bolder sound. While this exercise in jazz fusion was a brief phase, it was also an essential one. The albumâ€™s gorgeous story-songs, like the title track, and psychedelic saxophone parts courtesy of Mel Collins show the band at its most escapist. A minor work for King Crimson,  would have been the highlight of many other actsâ€™ discographies.Stream it on: Spotify, Apple MusicIf you like this, consider listening to: the Sailors Tales box set, from 2017. It collects every existing live show from this era, building a completist shrine out of what may have seemed like a curio.This marked the beginning of King Crimsonâ€™s most consistent lineup of the â€™70s. With the assistance of bassist/vocalist John Wetton and virtuosic drummer Bill Bruford, along with violinist David Cross and percussionist Jamie Muir, Fripp was able to conjure a deeper, darker sound.  spans relatively straightforward highlights like â€œEasy Money,â€ to classical-influenced set pieces like the two-part title track. With it came a period of King Crimsonâ€™s career in which composition and live improvisation shared equal billing. Essentially,  is the sound of a band figuring out how to incorporate the chaos around them into the songs themselves.Stream it on: Spotify, Apple MusicIf you like this, consider listening to: the live recordings from this era. They are just as essential and thereâ€™s no shortage of them to choose from. From the half-live follow-up album  to massive box sets like , you can hear King Crimson evolving with every performance.For an act often defined by its uncontainable adventurousness,  is a window into the sleeker side of King Crimson. At this point, the band was essentially a trioâ€”Robert Fripp on guitar, Bill Bruford on drums, and John Wetton on bass and vocalsâ€”and its songs were newly direct, both musically and lyrically. The title track is an instrumental proto-metal megalith, and the imagistic ballad â€œStarlessâ€â€”though 12 minutes longâ€”aims straight for the heart, with Wettonâ€™s poignant vocal delivery and Fripp's slow-building guitar solo. While most Crimson albums are notable for signalling rebirths,  is alone in feeling like a grand finale: the gripping conclusion to a half-decade of work, with not a note wasted. Itâ€™s one of King Crimsonâ€™s undeniable masterpieces.Stream it on: Spotify, Apple MusicIf you like this, consider listening to: Frippâ€™s work outside of Crimson. From his collaborative ambient masterpieces with Brian Eno (1973â€™s () and 1975â€™s ), to the daring art-pop album he produced for Daryl Hall (1980â€™s ), Frippâ€™s ambition kept him busy outside of the prog world he inspired.After a seven-year hiatus during the second half of the â€™70s, King Crimson marked their return with a new lineup, a new sound, and, if Fripp had had his way, a new name. Discipline was slated to be the moniker for this endeavor, featuring new recruits Adrian Belew on guitar and vocals and Tony Levin on bass and Chapman Stick. But after an early rehearsal, it became clear that this was no mere side projectâ€”it was the future of King Crimson, with a knotty, new wave sound that imagined if Talking Heads had met at music school instead of art school.  was the first in a trio of releases that found the band flirting, however hermetically, with the pop world in the form of music videos and dance remixes. Centered on the inventive guitar interplay between Fripp and Belew, the ever-cerebral material proved that Crimsonâ€™s DNA could sustain even the most dramatic reinvention.Stream it on: Spotify, Apple MusicIf you like this, consider listening to:  The â€™80s incarnation of Crimson did their best work in concert, and this retrospective release captures their final show of the decade, held in 1984. succeeds by doing exactly what you donâ€™t expect a King Crimson album to do: sound like King Crimson. Their sole studio full-length from the â€™90s is their most self-referential work (â€œDinosaurâ€ quotes the riff from 1970â€™s â€œCirkus,â€ while â€œVROOMâ€ calls back to the title track of ). Itâ€™s also among their most accessible. Adrian Belew is an unabashed Beatles fan, and these songs showcase the pop craftsmanship lurking beneath Crimsonâ€™s best work, from the quietly psychedelic â€œWalking on Airâ€ to the jumpy, philosophical â€œPeople.â€  was also a structural reinvention, introducing the â€œdouble trioâ€ formation of the group, with two of each instrument. Bigger in both sound and scope, itâ€™s the ideal late-career prog album.Stream it on: Spotify, Apple MusicIf you like this, consider listening to: 2003â€™s , which remains King Crimsonâ€™s most recent album of new material. It continues in â€™s path, led by Belewâ€™s nervy vocal style and familiar motifs from throughout the bandâ€™s discography.

Article: She alleges that the unnamed artist tried to force her to perform oral sex after a recording sessionAlunaGeorgeâ€™s Aluna Francis has described an alleged sexual assault by a collaborator whose identity has not been revealed. Speaking on BBC podcast â€œThe Next Episode,â€ Francis said the assault took place in the manâ€™s hotel room during a break from a recording session. She says she tried to reason with him. â€œHe pinned me down and heâ€™d taken his trousers down and he was trying to put his dick in my mouth,â€ Francis alleged. â€œSo I wrestled him off, and he was still laughing â€™cause he thought it was a game and that I was having a really fun time having a pretend rape situation.â€Francis added that it took time to realize the seriousness of what had happened, saying shame led her to â€œcompartmentalize all of this just for my career.â€ â€œMusicians are crazy ambitious about getting their craft out there,â€Â she said. When she confronted the man, she says he apologized and said, â€œThis has never happened before.â€ She said, â€œI thought that I was OK and Iâ€™m just so not.â€The podcast also includes accounts from Slow Clubâ€™s Rebecca Taylor and singer-songwriter ChlÃ¶e Howl. Taylor alleges that the visiting head of a U.S. label sexually assaulted her while â€œblind drunk.â€ Howl, meanwhile, described a situation where a member of her team became â€œpossessiveâ€ over her and allegedly began to sexually harass her.When reached by Pitchfork, representatives for AlunaGeorge offered no comment, but clarified that the unnamed collaborator is not Aluna Francisâ€™ bandmate George Reid.

An alternate version of a solo song by the Queen singerAn unearthed recording of Freddie Mercury performing â€œTime Waits for No One,â€ released in 1986 for Dave Clarkâ€™s musical , aired today on BBC Radio 2. The piano rehearsal was long thought lost, according to the BBC, but was rediscovered by Clark, who oversaw a rerecording of the piano part. Listen to it below.Last year, Mercury was portrayed by Rami Malek in the wildly successful Queen biopic Bohemian Rhaposdy. The role earned Malek the Oscar for Best Actor at the 2019 Academy Awards, as well as the Golden Globe for Best Actor.  also nabbed the award for Best Motion Pictureâ€”Drama at the Golden Globes.Read Pitchforkâ€™s List feature â€œ50 Songs That Define the Last 50 Years of LGBTQ+ Pride.â€

â€œThatâ€™s Lifeâ€ is 88-Keysâ€™ first solo song in 8 yearsProducer and rapper 88-Keys has shared a new track called â€œThatâ€™s Lifeâ€ featuring the late Mac Miller and Sia. Itâ€™s out now via 1801/Warner Records. Hear it below.â€œThatâ€™s Lifeâ€ was originally recorded in New York City while 88-Keys and Miller were in the studio together. It marks 88â€™s first song as a solo artist in eight years. Of the new song, 88 said in a press release:"Thatâ€™s Lifeâ€ is a song which sums up the sentiments of the music Iâ€™ve been working on over the past few years. We all have to forge through the good, the bad and the ugly. Mac came up with the concept for the song stemming from a conversation we had in the studio about relationships as we shared with each other what made the ones we were in at the time special. I played the song for Sia and she personally identified with the sentiments of the song and felt strongly about contributing her own thoughts on the subject matter. At the end of it all, my dear friend Mac and my new found friend Sia helped me make a song to touch the world and help many deal with adversities weâ€™re faced with, but â€œThatâ€™s Life.â€Sia recently released LSD, her joint LP with Labrinth and Diplo. Mac Millerâ€™s last album was 2018â€™s Swimming. He died later that year at the age of 26.Read â€œRemembering Mac Millerâ€™s Cultivation of Himself and His Peersâ€ on the Pitch.

Heâ€™s also releasing a Netflix short film directed by Paul Thomas AndersonThom Yorke has detailed his â€œdystopianâ€ new solo album: ANIMA is out June 27 via XL. Yorke wrote and produced  with Nigel Godrich. Check out the tracklist below. The vinyl edition of  includes the bonus track â€œLadies & Gentlemen, Thank You for Coming.â€Along with the LP, Yorke is releasing a â€œone-reeler,â€ made with frequent collaborator Paul Thomas Anderson. In a teaser clip, Yorke defines a one-reeler as â€œa motion picture, especially a cartoon or comedy, of 10-12 minutes duration and contained on one reel of film; popular especially in the era of silent films.â€ According to a press release, itâ€™s set to three tracks from the LP. The  one-reeler hits Netflix on June 27.Yorke will release  in multiple formats; digitally, on CD, and as two different vinyl editions. The standard double vinyl edition comes on two 140 gram black disks and includes a 10th track (â€œLadies & Gentlemen, Thank You for Comingâ€). Yorke will also release a deluxe double vinyl edition, complete with a hardback lyric book containing drawings by Stanley Donwood and Dr. Tchock, two orange 180 gram vinyl disks, as well as the additional track â€œLadies & Gentlemen, Thank You for Coming.â€Keen fans will notice the inclusion of a song called â€œDawn Chorusâ€ in the tracklist for . Itâ€™s the title of a song that Yorke and his Radiohead bandmates have had for years, but never released on an album. The band repurposed the name for the company they formed ahead of the release of  in 2016.Yorkeâ€™s announcement follows a string of new music: In April, he debuted two new compositions (â€œGawpersâ€ and â€œDonâ€™t Fear the Lightâ€) at the â€œMinimalist Dream Houseâ€ concert at the Philharmonie de Paris.Yorkeâ€™s last studio LP as a solo artist was 2014â€™s Tomorrowâ€™s Modern Boxes. In 2018, he composed the score to Luca Guadagninoâ€™s  remake. Yorke heads out on tour soon. Get tickets here. Listen to the track belowOver the past decade, Caroline Polachek has led several artistic lives over. As half of beloved indie pop group Chairlift, she wielded her bright falsetto like a secret weapon, detonating their groove-based songs with blasts of vitality, sadness, or both. The laptop-bred alter ego Ramona Lisa allowed Polachek to turn inward, crafting melodic, pastoral pop songs that paved the way for CEP, an ambient side project of â€œusefulâ€ music for passive activities. Now, with the arrival of â€œDoor,â€ a song simply credited to Caroline Polachek, a new sense of significance lingersâ€”in what direction does a musical polyglot go when presenting a project attributed only to herself?Airy and sprawling, â€œDoorâ€ is as elliptical and strange as Chairliftâ€™s most unconventional moments, but shot through with a romantic open-heartedness thatâ€™s all Polachek. Her diaphanous voice flits through various processors, sounding like sheâ€™s singing from another room entirely at one point before returning to a liquid, cool delivery. The kaleidoscopic, essential video renders the song in surreal visions of endless mirrors, doorways, and warped fields, with Polachek and a pair of greyhounds as guiding spirits. Taking an understated, strange approach to the pro forma pop song, â€œDoorâ€ coasts on gentle programmed drums, finger-picked acoustic guitar, and synths as sharp as gasps. But itâ€™s Polachekâ€™s wistful, memorable hook, journeying through a series of doorways to someone forever on the other side, that pushes â€œDoorâ€ to its peak. Collapsing into an agile vocal solo, â€œDoorâ€ ends on an ethereal and emotive note, providing an off-kilter introduction to a new era of Polachekâ€™s spare pop music.

The sketch series, co-produced by the Lonely Island, gets a second season next yearâ€œI Think You Should Leave with Tim Robinsonâ€ has been picked up for a second season by Netflix. The idiosyncratic sketch comedy series, created by former â€œSNLâ€ cast member Tim Robinson and Zach Kanin, will return to the streaming platform in 2020, with the Lonely Island and Irony Point set to return as producers. The first season, which premiered this past spring, focuses on placing characters in deeply uncomfortable situations.The Lonely Island recently released a new Netflix â€œvisual poem,â€ The Unauthorized Bash Brothers Experience, and issued their  soundtrack on vinyl for the first time.

Producer who worked with Phoenix, Kanye, Cat Power, and more was set to release a new Cassius album on FridayPhilippe Zdar, one-half of the influential French house duo Cassius, has died. He was 52, according to The New York Times. His agent confirmed the news in a statement sent to Pitchfork, saying Zdar accidentally fell from â€œa high floor of an old building in Paris.â€Cassius was a collaboration between Philippe Zdar, who was born Philippe Cerboneschi, and Hubert Blanc-Francard (known in the group as Boom Bass). Originally called La Funk Mob, they began recording and producing in the late â€™80s and early â€™90s. Their debut Cassius album was  (released that year). Their 2016 album Ibifornia featured Pharrell, Beastie Boysâ€™ Mike D, Cat Power, and others. Their new album  was set for release this Friday, June 21.Zdar was also the owner of the esteemed Motorbass studio in Paris. In the â€™90s, Zdar was a member of a duo also called Motorbass. Outside his work with Cassius, he did production and engineering work on albums by Phoenix (, which earned him a Grammy), Cat Power (), and the Rapture (). He recorded Kanye West on the Cassius-inspired  song â€œWhy I Love You.â€

â€œI feel totally out of control of most things in the world, but can at least build landscapes for the mindâ€Caroline Polachek (formerly of Chairlift) has released a new single called â€œDoorâ€ via Columbia Records. The trackâ€™s written and produced by Polachek, Dan Nigro, Danny L Harle, and Jim-E Stack. The video, directed by Polachek and Matt Copson, moves through a series of portals. Watch it below.â€œDoorâ€ is Polachekâ€™s first new song released under her full name. According to a press release, itâ€™s â€œthe first taste of a forthcoming, larger solo project from [Polachek] to be released later this year.â€ In a statement, Polachek said, â€œI feel totally out of control of most things in the world, but can at least build landscapes for the mind.â€Caroline Polachek has previously released albums under the monikers CEP (2017â€™s Drawing the Target Around the Arrow) and Ramona Lisa (2014â€™s Arcadia).Read Pitchforkâ€™s 2014 interview with Polachek.

The new movie, from  director Ari Aster, hits theaters in JulyMidsommar is the new film from Hereditary director Ari Aster. It hits U.S. theaters on July 3 (via A24). The couple goes on a trip to a Swedish village, but â€œwhat begins as a carefree summer holiday in a land of eternal sunlight takes a sinister turn when the insular villagers invite their guests to partake in festivities that render the pastoral paradise increasingly unnerving and viscerally disturbing.â€Bobby Krlic has previously worked on the scores for the documentary Almost Holy, the Netflix show â€œSeven Seconds,â€ and more. â€œDenver Haircutâ€ is the first track on The Hold Steady have announced a new album. Thrashing Thru The Passion is out August 16 via Frenchkiss. The record includes five previously released tracksâ€”â€œEntitlement Crew,â€ â€œT-Shirt Tux,â€ â€œStar 18,â€ â€œThe Stove & The Toaster,â€ and â€œConfusion in the Marketplaceâ€â€”along with five brand new tracks. Check out one of those new songs, â€œDenver Haircut,â€ below.â€œâ€™Denver Haircutâ€™ is a story about a guy who has chance meet up that takes him to a few different locations before leaving him alone and cashless in a strange hotel room,â€ frontman Craig Finn said in a statement. â€œSteve Selvidge (guitarist) brought in the music to this song and everyone felt it immediately, it was really fun to play. The story unfolded quickly too. When recording, we remarked that it sounded like it could kick off an album... and so here we are.â€ is the Hold Steadyâ€™s first record since 2014â€™s Teeth Dreams. Itâ€™s also their first album with keyboardist Franz Nicolay since 2008â€™s Stay Positive.â€œIâ€™ve been saying for a few years nowâ€”since Franz came back- that this six piece lineup of the Hold Steady is the best band weâ€™ve ever been,â€ Finn said. â€œThe new songs recorded by this version of the band are super exciting to us. Itâ€™s been a very fun and creative period for the Hold Steady.â€:01 Denver Haircut

YouTube Music and Universal Music Group plan to upgrade 1,000 music videosYouTube Music and Universal Music Group have announced an initiative to remaster a series of iconic music videos. Over the next year, they plan to upgrade nearly 1,000 music videos, with new titles appearing each week. The first groups of videos to be remastered include works by Beastie Boys, Janet Jackson, Lady Gaga, and Tom Petty, as well as Nirvanaâ€™s â€œSmells Like Teen Spirit.â€ (Thatâ€™s a screenshot of the remastered clip above.) Watch a remastered version of Beastie Boysâ€™ â€œSabotageâ€ below.Many of the classic videos were made for now-outmoded formats, resulting in poor video and audio quality on todayâ€™s high-definition screens. Remastering the videos meant recreating them using material from their original formats, a process that required arduous archival work, according to The New York Times. â€œWe have sources coming from everything from original film to Digibeta, HDCAM to one-inch Cs and Betacam SPs to D2sâ€”and the format it was shot in isnâ€™t necessarily the format it was edited in,â€ Barak Moffitt, Universalâ€™s executive vice president of content strategy and operation told .â€œOnce that dirty coloring is removed, itâ€™s a lot more vital somehow,â€ Billy Idol, whoâ€™s had six clips upgraded, told . â€œIt gives these videos a chance against the modern high-quality definition. And Iâ€™m forever that age in these videos â€” itâ€™s kind of fantastic.â€

Watch the video for â€œSalted Caramel Ice Cream,â€ and check out their tour datesMetronomyâ€™s new album has been announced. Itâ€™s called , and itâ€™s out September 13 via Because Music. The follow-up to 2016â€™s Summer 08 features the previously shared single â€œLately,â€ and today, theyâ€™ve released a new song called â€œSalted Caramel Ice Cream.â€ Check out the new song in the visual below. Frontman Joseph Mount discussed the new album in a statement:What happens is when youâ€™re making music and you enter a world where
you have achieved some sort of celebrity no matter how large or small
you start to think about yourself in terms of legacy and what you're
going to leave behind and then you realise thatâ€™s limited to the
interest people have in you. In the end I feel completely comfortable
with it. The less importance you place in any art the more interesting
it can become in a way...Iâ€™m making music, Iâ€™m going to do some
concerts, I need to feed my children.The band are heading out on a headlining European tour later this year after a run of festivals this summer. Find those dates here, and grab tickets here. (Pitchfork may earn a commission from purchases made through affiliate links on our site.)

The single â€œis the first release off of Kamaiyahâ€™s forthcoming projectâ€Kamaiyah recently dropped her first new single of 2019. Itâ€™s called â€œWindowsâ€ and it features guest spots from Quavo and Tyga. Sheâ€™s now shared the music video, directed by Damien Sandoval. Check it out below.Kamaiyah made her debut in 2016 with A Good Night in the Ghetto. She followed up the mixtape with Before I Wake in 2017. According to a press release, her new single â€œis the first release off of Kamaiyahâ€™s forthcoming project,â€ which will arrive via 4Hunnid/Interscope.Revisit Pitchforkâ€™s 2016 Rising interview â€œSupa Dupa Fly: Kamaiyah Bosses Up.â€ Check out â€œWrestling With Tygaâ€ on Levels.

Inspired by their latest album, Life Pedal is a collaboration with EarthQuaker DevicesSunn O))) have unveiled a new guitar pedal, in collaboration with guitar effects company EarthQuaker Devices. Life Pedal is a limited, hand numbered, octave fuzz and distortion with boost, inspired by the bandâ€™s latest album, the Steve Albini-engineered Life Metal.  Itâ€™s the first artist-focused pedal by EarthQuaker. Check out a video of it below.Sun O))) is gearing up to head out on the West Coast leg of their â€œLet There Be Drone: Multiple Gains Stagesâ€ tour in September. Revisit Pitchforkâ€™s interview with Sunn O))).

Listen to the track belowOn Frankie Cosmosâ€™ series of brief EPs from earlier this year, , bandleader Greta Kline drew on the emotional contexts she perceived within various objects. Sitting solo at a piano, Kline told the stories of these items in relation to her own existence; her minimal instrumentation mimicked her equally personal, solitary lyrics. On â€œWindows,â€ the lead single from Frankie Cosmosâ€™ forthcoming album Close It Quietly Kline returns to her guitar and full band with a broader theme to match: â€œlearning to see yourself as part of the whole.â€ Those objects she once saw as discrete miniatures now flood together as a massive galaxy, in which Kline seeks her space as a single star.Kline gazes through windows out onto a grand new view. â€œI know how to forgive those/Sceneries for surrounding me/But you did it differently,â€ she sings, nodding to a relationship thatâ€™s steered her off course. Looking to her internal compass, she embraces her blunders as she pieces herself back together: â€œDo I have regrets? Certainlyâ€¦ Do I bounce? I bounce back,â€ she promises, backed by subtly sparkling synths and cymbal hits. Thereâ€™s a place in the world for Kline, and though the ride there may be bumpy, she fits as seamlessly as the final piece of a jigsaw puzzle.

This fall, heâ€™s bringing the groupâ€™s improvisational shows to Broadway,  reports. , which features an unannounced rotating cast every night, begins previews in September and is set to run until January at the Booth Theater.Miranda announced the show on â€œThe Tonight Show,â€ saying that he plans to perform at the shows and hinting that Black Thought could show up as well. Freestyle Love Supreme started in 2004. Theyâ€™ve performed around the world, had a short-lived TV show, and recently had a run Off Broadway.  stars Christopher Jackson and Daveed Diggs have made appearances.Miranda is currently working on a film version of his Tony-winning music , which is produced by JAY-Z.https://twitter.com/FallonTonight/status/1141193230446469191

He was arrested for gun possession at his Dave & Busterâ€™s birthday party last AugustIn August 2018, Young Thug (birth name: Jeffery Williams) was arrested for felony gun possession after several guns, including an AK-47, were found in cars belonging to Thug and his associates. According to the Blast, a search took place after â€œone of Thugâ€™s cars bumped a squad car belonging to the police department.â€ He was searched and arrested during a birthday and listening party event held at Dave & Busterâ€™s in Hollywood.Now, the case has been dropped, TMZ reports. The District Attorneyâ€™s office rejected the case due to â€œinsufficient evidence.â€ Pitchfork has reached out to Thugâ€™s representatives for comment.

Article: Spice, So Solid Crew, Ms Dynamite, Lapalux, Shy One, and more are set for the month-long festFor the first time, Red Bull Music Festival is launching in London. Over the course of 16 events around the city, the inaugural London edition will host performances from Aphex Twin, So Solid Crew, Ms Dynamite, object blue, Shy One, Lapalux, and others. The schedule also features a Hyperdub takeover, production workshops open to female and female-identifying music makers, a talk with journalist Joe Muggs and photographer Brian David Stevens about their new book , as well as a conversation between dancehall legend Spice and Sian Anderson. Find the full lineup and schedule below. Red Bull Music Festival London 2019 takes place August 20-September 14.Red Bull recently announced that Red Bull Music Academy and Red Bull Radio would close this October. Read the Pitch piece, â€œWhatâ€™s Really Behind the Shuttering of Red Bull Music Academy?â€

Article: Best New TrackRead the Review

Last month, Apple brought back the iPod. Supposedly. On May 28, the tech giant announced the seventh-generation iPod Touch, which is essentially a stripped-down version of a smartphone, or a smaller, cheaper iPad (the price starts at $199). Still, itâ€™s technically Appleâ€™s first new iPod model since 2015.Music lovers have no reason to care about this device. The iPod Touch has little in common with the beloved iPod Classic (discontinued in 2014), or even the Shuffle and Nano (put out to pasture in 2017). But if you, like me, involuntarily perked up a little at the thought of Apple bringing back the iPod, this gadget is just another disappointing reminder of how far gone that era really is.Apple has claimed this latest iPod Touch is twice as fast as its predecessors, and hey, itâ€™s zipping along just fine during my early use. Games and augmented reality purportedly work better on this iPod Touch than previous iPod Touches. But the computer hardware facilitating this increased speed is the same processor found in the iPhone 7, the oldest iPhone model the company sells today. If you have seen or used an iPhone at any point in the past 10 years, you already have a good idea of what itâ€™s like to use this iPod. There is one feature that will appeal to audiophiles who are still resisting the transition to wireless headphones: It has a honest-to-goodness headphone jack.Actually listening to music on this thing is, yes, pretty much exactly the same as listening to music on an iPhone. The device seamlessly tapped into my collections on Apple Music and Spotify and eventually synced manually via my desktop iTunes; YouTube played videos as YouTube does. Honestly, the biggest trouble was, with nearly identical shiny rectangles sitting side by side on my desk, it was hard to know which one to pick up to make a phone call.This is all a far cry from what was once remarkable about the iPod. As Hazel Cills noted in this space in 2015, the iPod was a device for , and its enduring appeal had to do with  everything else a smartphone can do. â€œThe benefits of an iPod are the ability to literally contain your entire music library and ... to enjoy it without the temptation to blindly scroll through Instagram or tweets while you do so,â€ she wrote. Streaming music is a tradeoff for the sake of convenience, which Apple (and Spotify, and the music industry at large) has none too subtly pushed many of us to make. But itâ€™s not the same as MP3 ownership, as losing yourself in music that you painstakingly compiled and put on an iPod because you just needed Joanna Newsomâ€™s discography on you at all times, Wi-Fi access be damned.With streaming now constituting 75 percent of industry revenue (and growing), Appleâ€™s recent decision to start phasing out iTunes, at least as an app for storage purposes, feels almost moot. Partly by consumersâ€™ own choice and partly because tech companies left us with no other choice, the concept of owning music and listening to it on a dedicated player has gone from mainstream to niche in the matter of a few years. Download sales, which represented 42 percent of the industry in 2013, were down to an 11 percent share of the market last year. My old iPod has been sitting idle in a dresser drawer since well before that. Something new awaits, but those years of personally downloaded and assembled playlists, which could be listened to without distractions from other apps, are resoundingly done.

Listen to the track belowItâ€™s been 10 years since Sam Shepherd began releasing music as Floating Points, and on his very first releasesâ€”the breakbeat-fueled â€œK&G Beat,â€ the sashaying â€œVacuum Boogieâ€â€”the UK producer directed his focus squarely at the dancefloor. Over the past decade, Floating Pointsâ€™ music has gotten looser and more diffuse, dissolving from the jazz-kissed garage of 2011â€™s  EP to the vaporous, improvisatory , his masterpiece to date. But with his new single â€œLesAlpx,â€ Shepherd returns to those long-dormant dancefloor instincts.â€œLesAlpxâ€ is as driven a track as Shepherd has ever made, and as stripped bare: The bulk of it is taken up by a swinging, unstoppable drum groove. He brings color to the insistent, one-note bassline by dialing in a glowing layer of overtones in constant flux, his fingers restless on the knob. Itâ€™s an exercise in careful restraintâ€”until it isnâ€™t. First, an even boomier bass throb, unfathomably deep, cracks the space wide open; then, after a fadeout and false ending, he goes full prog, picking up the beat and laying on a lugubrious synthesizer melody that is the precise opposite of his spring-loaded drums, as though his coiled clockworks were suddenly replaced by one of Salvador DalÃ­â€™s melting clocks. Itâ€™s music befitting a sci-fi epic, or a sorcererâ€™s rites.

The quietly powerful singer-songwriter talks about the casual collaborations, ghostly coincidences, and subtle moments of enlightenment that make up his finest record yet.Balancing tradition with iconoclasm, this restless young artist is spearheading a fresh take on global pop.Photos and write-ups of sets by Beach House, Fever Ray, Deerhunter, Skepta, Lorde, BjÃ¶rk, and moreIn which the producer nearly sleeps through a festival set, puts a grown man in a headlock, and takes us on a very perilous motorcycle ride.During the reign of techno, trip-hop, and whatever â€œelectronicaâ€ was, these records were rumbling below the surface.Laurel Halo, Zola Jesus, Young Marco, and more make the year-end favorites from our monthly columnIncluding form-busting records by Jlin, Fever Ray, Yaeji, Mount Kimbie, and moreThe flamboyant young singer twists and bends languages, fashion trends, and musical styles to her will.The London-based producer talks about creating her strongest tracks during the most harrowing time of her life, and how being a parent helps her focus and be original.With an endless amount of gear out there, setting up your first home studio can seem like a daunting task. But it doesnâ€™t have to be.Inspired by Japanese electronic music from 1980s, this Portland duo embrace the distortionsÂ that arise when cultures are crossed.The unceasingly curious composer on chance, minimalism, and the politics of form.

The festival returns to La Grande Halle de La Villette from October 31 to November 2Pitchfork is excited to announce the first round of artists slated to perform at Pitchfork Music Festival Paris 2019. Headliners include Skepta, who recently released his album Ignorance Is Bliss; Chromatics, who are on their first tour in over five years; Belle and Sebastian, Mura Masa, Hamza, and Charli XCX, whoâ€™s set to drop her long-awaited third record Charli this summer. Pitchfork Music Festival Paris 2019 takes place from October 31 to November 2 at La Grande Halle de la Villette in the 19th arrondissement, the home of Pitchfork Paris since 2011.Other artists on the lineup include: Ateyaba, Barrie, Briston Maroney, Celeste, Desire, Ezra Collective, Flohio, Helado Negro, In Mirrors, Jackie Mendoza, Jamila Woods, Jessica Pratt, Kojey Radical, Korantemaa, Master Peace, NilÃ¼fer Yanya, Orville Peck, slowthai, Weyes Blood, Yussef Dayes, and ScÃ¨ne Konbini Radio. More artists will be announced in the following weeks.Pitchfork Music Festival Paris 2019 is set to be the festivalâ€™s biggest year yet, featuring over 50 acts and housing Avant-Gardeâ€™s up-and-coming acts within the walls of Grande Halle for the first time. Three-day passes are on sale now at the Pitchfork Paris website. Follow @PitchforkParis on Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook for updates.

(Pitchfork may earn a commission from purchases made through affiliate links on our site.)â€œIâ€™ve been in a state of constant motion for the past eight years or so; touring, moving, playing new stages, exploring new places and meeting new peopleâ€”an incredible time of learning and growing as a musician and performer,â€ Chelsea Wolfe said in a statement. â€œBut after awhile, I was beginning to lose a part of myself. I needed to take some time away from the road to get my head straight, to learn to take better care of myself, and to write and record as much as I can while I have â€˜Mercury in my hands,â€™ as a wise friend put it.â€:01 The Mother Road

is out this September via Sub PopFrankie CosmosÂ have announced a new record called â€”out September 6 via Sub Pop. The lead single â€œWindowsâ€ arrives with a music video directed by Eliza Doyle and Frankie Cosmos frontperson Greta Kline. The visual captures a day in New York. Watch below.â€œThis song takes place during the waiting period of healing, not knowing how to proceed or how to find the path to forgiveness,â€ Greta Kline said of â€œWindowsâ€ in a statement. â€œThe inner versus the outerâ€”learning to see yourself as part of the whole. For me the lyrics cover some of the slow movements of relationships, the shifts that occur in ways of thinking over time.â€Frankie Cosmosâ€”Kline, Lauren Martin (synth), Luke Pyenson (drums), and Alex Bailey (bass)â€”recorded  in Brooklyn with engineer/co-producer Gabe Wax. Itâ€™s the bandâ€™s follow-up to 2018â€™s Vessel.Frankie Cosmos head out on tour in September. Find their schedule at the bandâ€™s website. Get tickets here. Article:
â€œItâ€™s clearly something to be respected and faced head onâ€”but Iâ€™ve faced obstacles beforeâ€Megadeth co-founder and frontman Dave Mustaine has been diagnosed with throat cancer, he revealed today (June 17). â€œItâ€™s clearly something to be respected and faced head onâ€”but Iâ€™ve faced obstacles before,â€ he wrote. â€œIâ€™m working closely with my doctors, and weâ€™ve mapped out a treatment plan which they feel has a 90% success rate. Treatment has already begun.â€In his statement, Mustaine said Megadeth are canceling their upcoming tour dates. He also wrote that his bandmatesâ€”bassist David Ellefson, guitarist Kiko Loureiro, and drummer Dirk Verbeurenâ€”are working on Megadethâ€™s follow-up to 2016â€™s . Find Dave Mustaineâ€™s full message below.Dave Mustaine, a vocalist and guitarist, co-founded Megadeth in the mid-â€™80s after he was fired from Metallica. The group released its debut  in 1985. Megadeth have been nominated for 12 Grammy Awards, including Best Metal Performance, which they won in 2017 for â€œDystopia.â€Mustaine has made a number of controversial remarks in recent years. In 2012, he endorsed the far-right conspiracy that Barack Obama was not born in the United States. In addition, during a concert that year, Mustaine said he believed President Obama was â€œstagingâ€ shootings in Aurora, Colorado and at a Sikh temple in Wisconsin.

Late in the new film , there is a sequence soundtracked by Scott McKenzieâ€™s 1967 hippie standard â€œSan Francisco (Be Sure to Wear Flowers in Your Hair).â€ But instead of using the cheeseball original version, director Joe Talbot commissioned a gorgeous cover sung by Michael Marshall, best known for his hook on the Bay Area rap anthem â€œI Got 5 on It.â€ For the revamp, Talbot also drafted Norwegian jazz artist Daniel Herskedal, whose tuba playing is meant to evoke the foghorns of Hunters Point, the historically African-American neighborhood where much of the movie is set. Like the film itself, the soulful cover is steeped in Bay Area specificity, built from unlikely inspirations, and born of a deep collaborative spirit. is Talbotâ€™s debut feature and much of it was inspired by the life of Jimmie Fails, who plays the filmâ€™s main character, also named Jimmie Fails. The movie is ostensibly about Failsâ€™ attempt to reclaim a Victorian house in the Fillmore District built by his grandfather, but really itâ€™s about him trying to figure out his place in a city thatâ€™s in the final stages of an irrevocable identity change brought on by gentrification.Talbot and Fails met as kids, when Talbot was, as he puts it, â€œthe white kid that made beats for a lot of local rappers.â€ His longtime obsession with music is felt in the film through his inventive use of Jefferson Airplaneâ€™s â€œSomebody to Loveâ€ and Joni Mitchellâ€™s â€œBlue,â€ but also in the hilarious cameos from San Francisco icons like the Dead Kennedysâ€™ Jello Biafra, who plays a Segway-riding tour guide, and the rapper San Quinn.  is also bolstered by a score from composer Emile Mosseri, whose stirring pieces add depth to moments when victory is within grasp or when the realization of failure hits. Speaking over the phone about the details of his filmâ€™s sweeping soundtrack, Talbot says, â€œMusic is the only thing that I think I love more than movies.â€Joe Talbot: Yeah. I grew up in a very musical household. My dad in particular raised me on a lot of the great music from the â€™60s in San Franciscoâ€”Jefferson Airplane, Moby Grape, Big Brother [and the Holding Company]. And movie scores, too. My parents played  soundtrack and . And sometimes all those things would combine. Iâ€™d sample some weird soundtrack or an old San Francisco song for a beat that I was making. One of the first beats I made was this terrible, butchered version of the song thatâ€™s in the movie, Scott McKenzieâ€™s â€œSan Francisco.â€Itâ€™s a funny one, because my parents are old San Francisco lefties, and for a lot of people, including them, that song was seen as a hokey slice of hippie pop. It was written by John Phillips of the Mamas & the Papas as sort of marketing material: Local authorities were afraid of all the kids descending on Monterey for Monterey Pop, so he wrote that song to assuage their anxieties.So my parents didnâ€™t play that song, but I kind of loved it when I heard it because, by that time, it felt warm and nostalgic. San Francisco has this obsession with its past, and music from that â€™60s period conjures very strong feelings from people who lived through it and even for people like me, who were raised on stories of that time. When we started thinking about this movie, we wanted to take music from that period and update it into a newer, darker, stranger San Francisco that lives in a more perilous place. We were thinking about who could add a new twist to these old standards. Michael Marshall was one of the first people we thought about, and the first time he sang â€œSan Francisco,â€ it moved us to tears.Jello embodies a certain part of what I feel like is being lost in San Francisco. He has that great, twisted sense of humor. He came into our first audition with like 20 different possible outfits. I think he reveled in being a shithead in the film a little bit, which is why Jello is great.San Quinn is another one of those guys. I grew up listening to him. Whatâ€™s interesting about Quinn is heâ€™s got that beautiful, deep, almost preacher-ly voice. Heâ€™s also this great orator. In some ways, it was too bad we didnâ€™t get to use more of him, because heâ€™s an incredible storyteller. Heâ€™ll just sit with you and tell you about Mac Dre and what happened in Kansas City [where Mac Dre was shot and killed in 2004]. Heâ€™ll talk about what Fillmore was like and the beef between people that lived in Victorians versus the kids in the projects. Heâ€™s part of the fabric of the city.Oftentimes, making beats can be a gateway into tracking down the original music, and you get into music through something that was sampled in a rap song. I first heard Mac Dreâ€™s song where he samples â€œBlueâ€ at a funeral for someone I knew who had been killed when I was a teenager. It always stuck with me because it wasnâ€™t the music I would expect to hear at a funeral. But it was one of that kidâ€™s favorite songs. I eventually found out where it came from. I must have been playing it, and my dad was like, â€œSomeone fucking sampled Joni Mitchell?â€ Initially I wanted to use Mac Dreâ€™s song [in the scene] as well, but unfortunately he hadnâ€™t cleared the rights.I wrote some music before we actually even wrote the script to help me flesh out the world and think about what the movie could look like and feel like but, to be honest, I just didnâ€™t have anywhere near the chops to do the score. I spent a lifetime around music and working on it in some way, but there are so many things I donâ€™t know.Early on, I had these hopes of working with the people that made the music for films that I had grown up on, like Carter Burwell or Danny Elfman. But I realized that on an indie film like this, particularly with me being a first-time director, guys like that were most likely not going to allow me the kind of back-and-forth I was able to have in every other part of this film. Music is so important to the feeling in this film that the idea that I wouldnâ€™t be able to get my grubby little hands in there and actually work with someone made me really nervous.But when I met Emile, we bonded; he and I talk every day, still. Heâ€™s really grounded and not afraid, so he would let me be in there singing him shit and never be like, â€œHey man, get the fuck out here. Let me do my thing.â€ It was really collaborative, and he wanted to honor this thing I had been living with for five years. He actually listened to my input and then took it to levels I hoped for but never imagined.
Entities: ['Scott McKenzieâ€™s', 'Your Hair', 'Joe Talbot', 'Hunters Point', 'Talbotâ€™s', 'Jimmie Fails', 'Jimmie Fails', 'Jefferson Airplane', 'Joni Mitchell', 'Emile Mosseri', 'Moby Grape', 'Big Brother', 'John Phillips', 'Mamas & the Papas', 'San Quinn', 'Mac Dre', 'Mac Dre', 'Joni Mitchell', 'Mac Dreâ€™s']

Article: The guest-packed visual also features Ellen, Laverne Cox, Adam Rippon, and other LGBTQ iconsTaylor Swift has enlisted a slate of friends, frenemies, and LGBTQ figures for the â€œYou Need to Calm Downâ€ video, which you can watch below. The video includes appearances from RuPaul, Ellen Degeneres, Laverne Cox, figure skater Adam Rippon, and other celebrities including Ciara and Ryan Reynolds. They party in a cartoonish field while homophobic protestors look on waving placards.Toward the end, as a celebrity food fight roars behind them, Katy Perry appears in a beef burger costume. Taylor catches her eye and gives her a big french-fry hug. The pair previously squashed their longstanding beef with a similarly literal image: an actual wreath of olive branches.â€œYou Need to Calm Downâ€ is the second single from the singer-songwriterâ€˜s new album , out August 23 via Republic. The lead single â€œME!â€ featured Brendon Urie of Panic! at the Disco.  will be Taylorâ€™s first album following 2017â€™s reputation.

          Norman Fucking Rockwell is the follow-up to Lanaâ€™s 2017 album Lust for Life. Ahead of the new record (which has yet to receive a release date) Lana has shared â€œhope is a dangerous thing for a woman like me to have - but i have it,â€ â€œVenice Bitchâ€ and â€œMariners Apartment Complex.â€ In May, Lana dropped a cover of Sublimeâ€™s 1996 hit â€œDoinâ€™ Time.â€Read Pitchforkâ€™s interview, â€œLife, Liberty, and the Pursuit of Happiness: A Conversation With Lana Del Rey.â€

The lyric annotation site claims that it can prove this using carefully placed apostrophesGoogle publishes lyrics directly in search pages, and Genius claims that the search engine giant lifted lyrics without permission. In a new report from the , representatives from Genius said the siteâ€™s â€œwatermarkedâ€ lyrics are showing up on Google. Representatives from Google say the company is currently investigating Geniusâ€™ claims.Geniusâ€™ watermark, established sometime around 2016, makes it so apostrophes within lyrics alternate between straight and curly single-quote marks (' and â€™) in the same sequence for every song. When you convert the two types of apostrophes to dots and dashes, they spell â€œred handedâ€ in Morse code.â€œOver the last two years, weâ€™ve shown Google irrefutable evidence again and again that they are displaying lyrics copied from Genius in their Lyrics OneBox,â€ Geniusâ€™ Chief Strategy Officer Ben Gross said in a statement. â€œThis is a serious issue, and Google needs to address it.â€â€œThe lyrics displayed in the information boxes on Google Search are licensed from a variety of sources and are not scraped from sites on the web,â€ a Google spokesperson said in a statement. â€œWe take data quality and creator rights very seriously, and hold our licensing partners accountable to the terms of our agreement. Weâ€™re investigating this issue with our data partners and if we find that partners are not upholding good practices we'll end our agreements.â€Google says its lyrics results come from a licensing partnership with the Canadian company LyricsFind. â€œWe do not source lyrics from Genius,â€ LyricFind Chief Executive Darryl Ballantyne told the  in a statement.

A collection of B-sides, remixes, and more has been released digitally for the first time, commemorating the LPâ€™s 15th anniversaryBeastie Boys have shared a deluxe version of their 2004 LP To the 5 Boroughs to celebrate the albumâ€™s 15th anniversary. The expanded digital edition features a handful of B-sides and rarities, as well as remixes by the likes of producer Just Blaze, Blur guitarist Graham Coxon, and more. The material is available digitally for the first time. Ch-check it out below.Beastie Boys announced the release on their Twitter account. â€œHello everybody,â€ they wrote. â€œ came out 15 years ago today. For the occasion, twelve rare tracks have just been released digitally in addition to the original 15 songs on the album.â€Last month, surviving Beastie Boys Michael Diamond (Mike D) and Adam Horovitz (King Ad-Rock) released a mini-documentary on Amazon Music commemorating the 25th anniversary of their fourth studio album, 1994â€™s Ill Communication. In 2018, Diamond and Horovitz published Beastie Boys Book, a massive tome featuring career-spanning anecdotes. More recently, Mike D and Ad-Rock embarked on a Spike Jonze-directed book tour following the memoir.Read â€œ Lets the World in on the Trioâ€™s Inside Jokesâ€ over on the Pitch.https://twitter.com/beastieboys/status/1139556806428991488?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1139556806428991488&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.rollingstone.com%2Fmusic%2Fmusic-news%2Fbeastie-boys-rare-to-the-5-boroughs-tracks-15th-anniversary-848661%2F

The man, 27, had an underlying condition, organizers sayA Bonnaroo attendee died after suffering a â€œmedical situationâ€Â on the festival campgrounds yesterday (June 15), festival organizers say (via The Tennessean). The 27-year-old Tennessee man, who was at the 80,000-capacity festival with his father, received CPR from medics minutes after being found unresponsive. He was pronounced dead after being moved to the hospital. Organizers said the victim appears to have had an underlying medical condition.Further details have not yet been released. Read the festivalâ€™s full statement below.The well-being of our patrons, staff, volunteers and artists is our
primary concern, and we work diligently to ensure the safest festival
possible. Yesterday, our medical team in Plaza 11 was asked to respond
to a medical situation in a nearby campsite. The Bonnaroo Medical team
and Coffee County Emergency Services were on the scene within minutes.
A 27-year-old male patron camping with his father was unresponsive.
The medical team administered CPR, and he was transported to the
hospital where he died. We understand that he had an underlying
medical condition, but we have no further information at this time.
Our thoughts and prayers go out to his family and friends.

Tay appeared onstage at the iconic LGBTQ+ bar in New York for an acoustic rendition of her  hit, wishing everyone a â€œhappy pride monthâ€Taylor Swift dropped by New Yorkâ€™s iconic LGBTQ+ bar the Stonewall Inn tonight (June 14) for an acoustic performance of her  hit â€œShake It Off.â€ She wished the crowd a â€œhappy pride month,â€ and invited actor Jesse Tyler Ferguson to sing along with â€œShake It Off.â€ Ferguson was present for an evening of performances at AEG and Stonewall Innâ€™s pride celebration commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall Uprising. The event was co-hosted by Diva Jackie Dupree and included performances by Sara Bareilles, Gavin Creel, Lea DeLaria, VINCINT and more.â€œI heard that this is Jesseâ€™s favorite song to do at karaoke,â€ Taylor said of â€œShake It Off.â€ â€œSo if thereâ€™s anything you feel like you want to jump in on, if thereâ€™s like, your part that youâ€™re really good at, then, just sing, dance, just be yourself. This is a really safe space.â€ Watch her intimate performance below.Taylor dropped her new song â€œYou Need to Calm Downâ€ yesterday, hours after announcing the title and release date of her reputation follow-up. Lover arrives August 23 via Republic. Tay shared â€™s lead single â€œME!â€ (featuring Brendon Urie of Panic! At The Disco) back in April.On June 1â€”the first day of Pride Monthâ€”Swift wrote an open letter to Tennesseeâ€™s Republican Senator Lamar Alexander in support of the Equality Act, an expansion of the Civil Rights Act that prohibits employers from discriminating against anyone because of their sexual orientation and/or gender identity.Read â€œOn Loving Taylor Swift While Being Brownâ€ on the Pitch.https://twitter.com/Variety/status/1139689061461848064https://twitter.com/swiftlovertour/status/1139689323178029057https://twitter.com/Variety/status/1139687270686969857

arrives in celebration of the Toronto Raptorsâ€™ first NBA titleAs promised, DrakeÂ has released two new songs to celebrate his beloved Toronto Raptorsâ€™ first NBA title. A phone number found on ads for â€œAnima Technologiesâ€ leads to a track the Radiohead frontman has been playing on tourMysterious ads for â€œAnima Technologiesâ€ have cropped up in multiple London trains, The Dallas Observer, and on phone booths  in Milan, prompting people to call a phone number (916-619-6192) that will retrieve their forgotten dreams. In fact, the number leads to a voice message claiming that â€œAnima technologies has been ordered by the authorities to cease and desist from undertaking its advertised business.â€ At the end of the message, a portion of Thom Yorkeâ€™s song â€œNot the Newsâ€ is played. The unreleased track is one Yorke has been performing on tour lately.A website for Anima Technologies was also created. A statement on the site claims it has been seized â€œdue to serious and flagrant unlawful activities.â€ Check out the ad for Anima Technologiesâ€”which purports to have developed a â€œdream cameraâ€ to preserve forgotten dreamsâ€”below.https://twitter.com/Fellwolf/status/1139145404371689473Back in April, Yorke debuted two new compositions (â€œGawpersâ€ and â€œDonâ€™t Fear the Lightâ€) at the â€œMinimalist Dream Houseâ€ concert at the Philharmonie de Paris. Yorkeâ€™s last studio LP as a solo artist was 2014â€™s Tomorrowâ€™s Modern Boxes. In 2018, he composed the score to Luca Guadagninoâ€™s  remake.Read Pitchforkâ€™s Live Review â€œThom Yorkeâ€™s Contemporary Classical Debut Is a Daring Triumphâ€ over on the Pitch.

Article:
â€œWe are happy to say that contrary to earlier news reports, the entire club was not affectedâ€Earlier this morning, a fire broke out at Club der VisionÃ¤re, an iconic riverside club venue in Berlinâ€™s Kreuzberg district, as  reports. According to tweets posted by the Berlin fire department, the club was left â€œburned out almost completelyâ€ as a result of the blaze, which was contained with the help of 70 on-scene emergency responders.Last night, Club der VisionÃ¤re was host to a birthday show for the Perlon-affiliated DJ/producer James Dean Brown, with multiple DJs from Tokyo on the bill in addition to Brown. The cause of the fire has yet to be reported at this time.Update (06/15, 12:59 p.m. Eastern): Club der VisionÃ¤re has issued a statement to clarify the extent of the damage to the space and confirm that no injuries occurred as a result of the fire. The full statement reads:Sadly, today at 8am an unfortunate fire broke out at Club der
Visionaere. Before providing more details, we would like to express
our extreme gratitude and relief that no one was injured in the
incident, including guests or staff.We are happy to say that contrary to earlier news reports, the entire
club was not affected, only a section of the upper level seating area
located under the weeping willow tree, which was closed at the time of
the fire. Once again, the club area itself was not effected.First measures were taken by staff who were trained and certified as
fire protection first responders staff. They ensured guests were
evacuated in a calm and controlled manner without injury.  The fire
department then extinguished the fire shortly after their arrival to
the scene.The cause of the incident is still unknown. Investigations are
ongoing. We would like to thank the Berlin police and fire department
for their effective response and continued commitment.We are now assessing the extent of the damage and hope to reopen soon
after consultation with authorities. Until then, we will keep on
keeping on by continuing the Club der Visionaere program at Hoppetosse
as of tomorrow/Sunday.We would also like to express our extreme gratitude to the tremendous
support in way of messages, posts, and offers of help from our local
and international Club der Visionaere family. Your presence really
does bring a much appreciated light to this otherwise darker moment.
As well, your expressed compassion reminds us of and highlights the
many warm relationships that have developed over the years. Thank you
so very much for your sincerely felt words and energy.

The song features a previously unheard beat from the late J Dilla. Watch the music video below, directed by Savanah Leaf.According to a press release, the â€œHERâ€ of â€œHER Loveâ€ stands for â€œ(Hip-Hop in its Essence is Real),â€ the same acronym made famous on Commonâ€™s 1994 single â€œI Used to Love H.E.R.â€ The song will appear on the rapperâ€™s next studio album, which will be released later this year and mark his first album since 2016â€™s Black America Again.Common will be on tour beginning this July; check out the full itinerary and buy tickets here. Yang Hyun-suk has resigned from the company he helped found over 20 years ago (Big Bang, Psy, BLACKPINK)YG Entertainment is one of the biggest music companies in the K-pop industry, one of the institutions considered a part of the â€œBig Threeâ€ label groups in South Korea (which also includes SM Entertainment and JYP Entertainment). Today, itâ€™s been announced that founder Yang Hyun-suk and his brother, CEO Yang Min-suk, have resigned from the company following sustained allegations of the companyâ€™s involvement in drug scandals involving artists that were signed to their roster, as Billboard reports.â€œIâ€™ve dedicated the past 23 years of my life to YG Entertainment. It was my greatest joy to support the best music and the best artists,â€ Yang Hyun-suk wrote in a statement posted to the YG Entertainment website earlier today. â€œFrom today onward, however, I have decided to step down from my responsibilities and positions at YG.â€Founded in 1996, YG has served the label home for various notable K-pop acts including Big Bang, Psy, and recently, BLACKPINK. The company came under scrutiny earlier this year after the â€œBurning Sunâ€ scandal, in which reports emerged that drug use and sexual abuse had taken place at the Burning Sun nightclub, owned by Big Bang member Seungri. On Tuesday, June 11, a whistleblower filed a report with South Koreaâ€™s Anti-Corruption and Civil Rights Commission regarding alleged collusion by the label to cover up a drug offense by another artist, the rapper and singer-songwriter B.I of iKON, as Korea Herald reports. This development led to Yang Hyun-sukâ€™s resignation earlier today.A member of the seminal K-pop group Seo Taiji & Boys in the 1990s, Yang became a household name in Korea through YG and his tenure as a judge on various South Korean singing competition shows in the 2010s. In concluding his resignation statement, Yang wrote: â€œFinallyâ€”through thorough investigation of the media reports and the facts, I believe that the truth will come to light.â€

Article: Durk and fellow OTF rapper King Von are each facing five felony charges, stemming from an Atlanta shootingA Fulton County, Georgia judge has found probable cause to charge rappers Lil Durk and King Von with criminal attempt to commit murder, local ABC affiliate WSB-TV reports. Durk turned himself in to authorities last month after a warrant was issued for his arrest in connection with a February 2019 shooting outside of an Atlanta restaurant called the Varsity. According to WSB-TV, prosecutors allege that Durk â€œis seen on video shooting a man near The Varsity while he was driving.â€According to Fulton County records, viewed by Pitchfork, Lil Durk and King Von are each facing five felony charges: Criminal Attempt to Commit Murder; Aggravated Assault; Participation in Criminal Street Gang Activity; Possession of Firearm During the Commission of a Felony; and Possession of Firearm by a Convicted Felon.Lil Durkâ€™s management offered no comment when contacted by Pitchfork. Pitchfork has reached out to representatives and attorneys for King Von.When reached by Pitchfork, Lil Durkâ€™s attorney stated that his client maintains his innocence at this time. Before turning himself in to authorities in May, Lil Durk told WSB-TV, â€œI have nothing to hide,â€ adding, â€œI have nothing to run from.â€
Entities: ['King Von', 'Lil Durk', 'King Von', 'The Varsity', 'Lil Durk', 'King Von', 'Aggravated Assault', 'Participation', 'Firearm', 'Lil Durkâ€™s', 'King Von', 'Lil Durkâ€™s', 'Lil Durk']

â€œIt will be a smart, funny workplace comedy full of commentary about everything from gentrification to sex to tech to call-out cultureâ€MTV Studios has clarified its plans for the reboot of â€™90s cult cartoon â€œDaria,â€ as The Hollywood Reporter notes. â€œJodieâ€ will focus on Dariaâ€™s friend Jodie Landon, who will be voiced by Tracee Ellis Ross. The series takes place in the years after Lawndale High and will follow Jodie as she enters the tech industry in her first job after college.Of the forthcoming show, Ross said in a press release:Being able to give voice to fresh, feminist and unexplored stories of
young women excites me. â€œJodieâ€ will spin off from the cult classic
â€œDaria,â€ and with the brilliant, sweet and sarcastic black-girl magic
that is Jodie Landon, we will feature a diverse cast, comprised mainly
of unapologetically smart and ambitious young female characters who
are vulnerable and flawed and interesting and funny. As a very cool
bonus, Jodie will be the first adult animated show in almost 20 years
that will star a black woman. It will be a smart, funny workplace
comedy full of commentary about everything from gentrification to sex
to tech to call-out culture.â€œJodieâ€ will reportedly be the first in a series of spinoff shows from MTV Studios, constituting a â€œâ€˜Dariaâ€™ universe.â€ A network for the cartoon has not yet been announced. Characters from the original â€œDariaâ€ series will make an appearance in the new spinoff.Last year, MTV Studios announced the new series â€œDaria & Jodie,â€ which was set to â€œreinventâ€ the original series â€œthrough the eyes of heroine Daria Morgendorffer and one of her closest friends Jodie Landon.â€ The show, which will still be written by Grace Nkenge Edwards, will now focus more closely on Jodie.â€œDariaâ€ was originally a spinoff of Mike Judgeâ€™s raunchy cartoon â€œBeavis and Butt-Head.â€ It ran for five seasons on MTV from 1997-2002.Tracee Ellis Ross recently starred in Tyler, the Creatorâ€™s IGOR visual â€œEARFQUAKE.â€ Last year, she appeared in Drakeâ€™s star-studded â€œNice for Whatâ€ music video.

â€œOmertÃ â€ and the Rick Ross-featuring â€œMoney in the Graveâ€ will arrive tomorrow to celebrate the Raptorsâ€™ victory over the WarriorsDrakeâ€”Toronto Raptors superfan, occasional nuisance, and global ambassadorâ€”will release two new songs tomorrow to celebrate his favorite teamâ€™s first NBA title. One is called â€œOmertÃ ,â€ and the other is a Rick Ross-featuring track called â€œMoney in the Grave.â€ He wrote: â€œTHE CHIP TO THE 6!!!!!!!!!!!!â€ Check out the artwork below.Tonight, in a post-game interview, Drake discussed the win with reporters. â€œWe did this off of heart. We did this off of love,â€ he said. â€œWe willed this into existence. We manifested this. I told you the first time. People like to make memesâ€”make another meme out of this. Itâ€™s beautiful.â€https://twitter.com/WordOnRd/status/1139391307405639680Drake has been especially vocal throughout the Raptorsâ€™ run to the NBA Finals. In May, during the Eastern Conference Finals, Drake interacted directly with Raptors coach Nick Nurse on the sideline. He was also criticized by Milwaukee Bucks fans for what they saw as disrespectful antics on the sidelines. Georgios Dimitropoulos (a senior executive at the European agency that used to represent Bucks superstar Giannis Antetokounmpo) tweeted, â€œNever seen anything as disrespectful as this before....â€ He later deleted the tweet.Following Dimitropoulosâ€™ tweet, Bucks coach Mike Budenholzer said:I donâ€™t know how much heâ€™s on the court. It sounds like you guys are
saying itâ€™s more than I realize. Thereâ€™s certainly no place for fans
and, you know, whatever it is exactly that Drake is for the Toronto
Raptors. You know, to be on the court, thereâ€™s boundaries and lines
for a reason, and like I said, the league is usually pretty good at
being on top of stuff like that.Drake, in turn, responded indirectly with photos and emoji. Following the Raptorsâ€™ series victory over the Bucks, NBA officials spoke with Drake about his behavior.During Game 1 of the NBA Finals against the Golden State Warriors, Drake wore Dell Curryâ€™s No. 30 Toronto Raptors jersey (pictured above). Dell Curry played for the Raptors from 1999 to 2002. His son, Stephen Curry, has won three NBA titles with the Warriors.Also during Game 1, Drake exchanged words with the Warriorsâ€™ Draymond Green. â€œWe talked; we barked a little bit. But I wouldnâ€™t necessarily consider it a scuffle. [It wasnâ€™t] what I personally would consider a scuffle,â€ Green said.Off the court, San Francisco radio station KBLX stopped playing Drakeâ€™s music during the Finals. â€œOur listeners are in absolute support of the stationâ€™s decision to ban all Drake music until the NBA finals are had by Stephen Curry and the Warriors,â€ KBLX program director Elroy Smith told Variety. â€œDrake started it by disrespecting the Warriors. His taunting toward the Warriors must stop.â€Read Pitchforkâ€™s op-ed feature â€œMy Dinner With Drake.â€
