Article: Music comes naturally to Diana Silvers. Last summer, the 21-year-old wandered into a Guitar Center, left with a bass guitar and amp, and started practicing her favorite classic rock and psychedelic tunes. Now, sheâ€™s proficient enough to upload those four-string covers to Instagram. And if she needs a backing band, she has one on standby: The Los Angeles native, who says she â€œprobably cares about music more than anything else,â€ likens her equally artistic family to the Von Trapps.Silversâ€™ talents, though, are typically found on the big screen. The fast-rising actress currently costars with Octavia Spencer in the thriller  and has an ensemble role in the coming-of-age comedy . In the former, Silvers plays an unassuming new girl in town whose friend group is invited to parties in a lonely womanâ€™s basement, unaware of their hostâ€™s gruesome intentions. In , Silvers plays Hope, a beautiful, standoffish classmate of over-studious best friends Molly (Beanie Feldstein) and Amy (Kaitlyn Dever), who delivers both sharp-tongued dismissals of her peers and an opportunity for the meek Amy to embrace her sexuality.As Hope, Silvers exudes effortless cool in a fringed vintage jacket and heavy-lidded stare. Offscreen, she has equally groovy taste in music: Pink Floyd, the Eagles, Fleetwood Mac, and other classics. Calling from California, Silvers tells us about the music sheâ€™s currently rocking.I used to make my dad mix CDs. He would tell me what songs to put on them, and one of them had â€œFoxey Lady.â€ Last summer, I got really into â€˜60s psychedelic music, and I finally listened to . I was like, â€œMan, this is incredible!â€ I think â€œThe Wind Cries Maryâ€ is my favorite Jimi Hendrix song. Obviously, heâ€™s one of the greatest guitarists of all time, but even his lyrics are really meaningful. In psychedelic rock, thereâ€™s so much going on and so many different sounds. You can go back and find new things to listen for, which is really special. I was reading something about how different frequencies in music make you feel certain ways; this album makes me feel like Iâ€™m high, even though I donâ€™t do drugs.The White Album is so cool because it was around the time when the Beatles started to not like each other, so they would each go off and do their own thing. Itâ€™s all over the place, but thatâ€™s what makes the album so brilliant. You can listen to each of their solo work, and then come back to this, and itâ€™s so obvious who did whatâ€”like, â€œthatâ€™s  a George song,â€ or â€œthatâ€™s  a Paul song.â€ The first time I really listened to the White Album was during my first heartbreak, in my freshman year of college. I really resonated with â€œLong, Long, Longâ€â€”itâ€™s so beautiful but so depressing. â€œRocky Raccoonâ€ and â€œDear Prudenceâ€ are my favorite Beatles songs, and I played â€œIâ€™m So Tiredâ€ a lot during finals week. The Beatles are my favorite band of all time, hands down.I truly believe Lorde is the voice of our generation. When a relationship ends, all you can do is play in your head everything that happened between you. I never knew what to call it, and then I heard â€œSupercut.â€ How did she know exactly how I felt, and encapsulate it so eloquently into this song that slaps? And â€œLiabilityâ€: â€œI am a toy that people enjoy/â€™Til all of the tricks donâ€™t work anymore.â€ Again, how did she know? She said it better than I could even  it. Sheâ€™s above us, yet sheâ€™s one of us. I was supposed to see Lorde on the  Tour in New York with my best friend, but then I got a callback for  in L.A. and couldnâ€™t make the concert. Thank God I got the part!

The bill is an expansion of the Civil Rights Act that prohibits employers from discriminating against anyone because of their sexual orientation and/or gender identity. â€œThe fact that, legally, some people are completely at the mercy of the hatred and bigotry of others is disgusting and unacceptable,â€ she wrote.â€œYou Need to Calm Downâ€ arrives two months after Taylor released her Brendon Urie-featuring single â€œME!.â€ A music video for the new single is slated to drop June 17. Article: Celebrating the labelâ€™s 30-year anniversary with mixes, live sessions, and other contributions from artists like Aphex Twin, Boards of Canada, Kelela, Oneohtrix Point Never, moreWarp Records has announced a three-day takeover on NTS Radio in the form of WXAXRXP, an â€œonline music festivalâ€ that will see the label celebrating their 30-year anniversary with over 100 hours of â€œexclusive mixes, live sessions, videos, unreleased material, new compositions and experimental free-form radio,â€ featuring contributions from various artists on the Warp rosters.Artists set to participate in some way include Aphex Twin, Boards of Canada, Kelela, Danny Brown, Oneohtrix Point Never, Hudson Mohawke, Brian Eno, Bibio, Flying Lotus, Squarepusher, Yves Tumor, and more. â€œSpecial guestsâ€ will be announced for the program as well. Boards of Canada will be playing a â€œmysterious two hour mix,â€ set to be the groupâ€™s first â€œpublic outingâ€ since the release of  in 2013. Autechre, Kelela, Hudson Mohawke, Mark Pritchard, Bibio, Clark, and DJ Nigga Fox are among the artists set to play previously unreleased music. There will also be new mixes from FlyLo, Danny Brown, !!!, Lorenzo Senni, Ryuichi Sakamoto, Shayne Oliver (Hood by Air), and others.WXAXRXP takes place June 21-23 and will broadcast here.Read our recent Sunday Review of Selected Ambient Works Volume II.

Article: New York-based singer-songwriter Raveena makes silky R&B that delves into trauma and maps out paths to healing. Her debut album, , begins in murky confusion, all warbled synth and whispered lyrics, as she obliquely addresses the people who have hurt her in the past. Gradually, over the course of 12 songs, her sound becomes bolder and clearer, finding strength in everything from sun showers to her motherâ€™s resilience to her own femininity and womanhood.â€œPetalâ€ ends the album on a euphoric note, wrapping layered vocals into a cocoon thatâ€™s delicate and full like a peony bloom. The songâ€™s catharsis doesnâ€™t come from conquering obstacles entirely, but from making peace with them. â€œPetalâ€ follows â€œNaniâ€™s Interlude,â€ in which Raveenaâ€™s grandmother talks about accepting the death of her husband as she faces her own mortality. On â€œPetal,â€ Raveena takes her grandmotherâ€™s advice to heart, finding joy in her own insignificance. She sings about feeling like â€œa speck inside an endless feed,â€ or â€œa petal floating in the breezeâ€; she ends by singing, â€œI am weightless/Knowing death is soon to come.â€ In any other context, the words would be morbid, but gliding in a celestial wash of falsetto and reverb, they sound freeing.

The movie, starring Keanu Reeves and Alex Winter, comes out in summer 2020Kid CudiÂ has joined the cast of Bill & Ted Face the Music. The film, directed by Dean Parisot and written by Chris Matheson and Ed Solomon, is set to begin production this summer.In the new movie, according to a synposis, Bill and Ted â€œset out on a new adventure, when a visitor from the future warns them that only their song can save life as we know it and bring harmony to the universe.â€

Check out a new visual for â€œI Remember Nothingâ€Joy Divisionâ€™s landmark 1979 album Unknown Pleasures is getting reinterpreted by 10 directors for the recordâ€™s 40th anniversary. â€œUnknown Pleasures: Reimaginedâ€ is a series of 10 new videosâ€”one for each track of the LP. Each visual will be created by a different filmmaker. Invisible Hitsâ€œLife isnâ€™t about finding yourselfâ€”or about finding ,â€ Bob Dylan says in Martin Scorseseâ€™s , out this week on Netflix. â€œLife is about creating yourself.â€ For well over half a century, Dylanâ€™s documentarians have been trying to capture that process in action. In many ways, their efforts are as essential to his myth as the music, even if these filmmakers often fail at fully decoding that myth. The very definition of a moving target, Dylan is impossible to pin downâ€”after all, heâ€™s the guy who boastingly sang â€œnothing is revealedâ€ back in 1967. But these documentaries from over the decades reveal plenty. They follow in chronological order, based on the time period they portray.Dylan was a mainstay at the annual Newport Folk Festival in Rhode Island every summer from 1963 to 1965, starting as a Guthrie-esque protest singer and ending up a folk-rock . Murray Lernerâ€™s  expertly tracks this metamorphosis. First, we see Dylan in 1963, performing such socially conscious tunes as â€œOnly a Pawn in Their Gameâ€ and earnestly leading a whoâ€™s-who of folk luminaries for a festival-closing â€œBlowinâ€™ in the Wind.â€ One year later, heâ€™s delivering a hallucinatory performance of â€œMr. Tambourine Man.â€ And then, most famously,  presents Dylanâ€™s 1965 â€œplugged-inâ€ debut, which split the folk world in two. The absolutely ferocious rendition of â€œMaggieâ€™s Farmâ€ from that day remains a complete thrill, with Dylan barking out the words over Michael Bloomfieldâ€™s screaming guitar. (You can rent or buy this movie via iTunes.)For a fuller picture of the Newport Folk Festivalâ€™s early days, check out Lernerâ€™s 1967 film , which features stellar performances by Mississippi John Hurt, the Staple Singers, Judy Collins, and many more.A few months before Dylan went electric at Newport, he embarked on a sold-out tour of England. Documentarian D.A. Pennebaker tagged along for the ride. His resulting film, , captures Bob playing solo acoustic to audiences whose reverence borders on the religious. Dylan, of course, is suspicious of such devotion, and  is highlighted by off-stage encounters with fans and press that are confrontational, to say the least. Itâ€™s a great fly-on-the-wall piece of documentary filmmaking, but it also works as a compelling drama. Using real-life situations and people (with the charismatic Dylan center stage), Pennebaker constructs a narrative as cohesive and complete as any fictional work. Added bonus:  famously kicks off with one of the great pre-MTV music videos, the much-imitated flip-card â€œSubterranean Homesick Bluesâ€ sequence.  (You can rent or buy this movie via Amazon or iTunes.)Dylan hired Pennebaker again for his candle-burning-at-both-ends 1966 European tour with the Hawks, who were soon to morph into The Band. This time, Pennebaker and his crew were shooting in full color, fitting the more hallucinatory sounds of this era. Following the tour, Dylan rejected the rough edit Pennebaker delivered, titled . Working in tandem with cameraman/editor Howard Alk, the songwriter used Pennebakerâ€™s footage to make , a disjointed anti-documentary that has only been shown a handful of times and never been released on home video. Too bad. Itâ€™s not an easy watch by any means, but  does feature plenty of incredible live clips and oddly beautiful cinematography, and offers valuable insight into Dylanâ€™s amphetamine-frazzled mid-â€™60s psyche.Martin Scorsese made Pennebakerâ€™s 1966 footage the connective tissue of his three-and-a-half-hour 2005 doc, , which traced Dylanâ€™s rise from his Minnesota childhood to his NYC coffeehouse days to his electric period. The filmâ€™s coup was securing its ever-cagey subjectâ€™s participationâ€”from a distance, at least, seeing as Dylanâ€™s manager interviewed him, not Scorsese. In some surprisingly candid segments taped in the early 2000s, Dylan provides a clear-eyedâ€”if still characteristically enigmaticâ€”account of his earliest days, complemented by interviews with Joan Baez, Suze Rotolo, Pete Seeger, and many others. A necessary deep-dive into Dylanâ€™s rise,  is also packed with fantastic performances, from solo acoustic protest anthems to dangerously high-flying excursions with the Hawks. (You can rent this movie via Amazon or iTunes.)The cameras were rolling constantly during Dylanâ€™s legendary Rolling Thunder Revue tour in the fall of 1975; apparently more than 90 hours of footage was shot. Dylan spent the next several years editing it all down into , a sometimes fascinating, often incomprehensible four-hour flick that was savaged by critics upon release and has never been released in any home video format (it makes regular appearances on YouTube, however). Now, Martin Scorsese and co. have trawled through the original footage to make . The performancesâ€”most of them previously unseenâ€”are exceptional. We see Bob and his band rehearsing in NYC; raging through a spellbinding â€œIsis,â€ Dylan  guitar, eyes wild; crashing a Massachusetts mahjong parlor; playing â€œThe Ballad of Ira Hayesâ€ at the Tuscarora Indian Reservation; and performing for a tiny group of inmates at Clinton State Prison in New Jersey.Even though  is practically a Ken Burns production compared to , the film is not an entirely straightforward doc. Alongside the usual talking heads, Scorsese throws in a fictional Dutch filmmaker, a wholly imaginary concert promoter, a Robert Altman characterâ€”and even Sharon Stone, claiming to have had an affair with Dylan during the tour. Bob plays along with all of it, sneakily avoiding the real-life turmoil that consumed him at the time. â€œWhen someoneâ€™s wearing a mask, heâ€™s gonna tell you the truth,â€ he claims in the film. But letâ€™s not forget that Dylan has opened virtually every one of his shows since 2013 with a song that includes the lines, â€œAll the truth in the world adds up to one big lie.â€ (You can stream this movie via Netflix.)The Rolling Thunder Revue reconvened in 1976, but the vibes on that tour were much less celebratory. Dylanâ€™s marriage was crashing and burning, his foul mood is on full display in , a doc filmed during a very wet Fort Collins, Colorado, stadium show. Howard Alkâ€™s camera captures Dylan in unflinching closeupsâ€”the viewer isnâ€™t in the crowd but rather right onstage, up in Dylanâ€™s face. Itâ€™s uncomfortable but still gripping, especially when he and his turban-wearing band deliver such feisty performances as a punk-tinged â€œShelter From the Storm,â€ a bawdily rewritten â€œLay Lady Lay,â€ and best of all, a harrowing â€œIdiot Wind.â€ Here, Dylan makes the threatening storm clouds above the stadium seem positively tame in comparison.Infamously, Dylan found Jesus in the late 1970s, recording three so-called â€œborn againâ€ LPs that left a hefty portion of his fanbase confused and disappointed. That era has been re-evaluated in recent years, thanks in part to the excellent 2017  release, . Included with that set was a fantastic new documentary, , featuring a wealth of gospel-tinged performances. Regardless of where you fall in the spiritual spectrum, Dylanâ€™s passionate intensity in these clips is utterly convincing, whether on fire-and-brimstone rockers like â€œSlow Train Comingâ€ or powerful slow jams for the Lord like â€œPressing On.â€ Best of all, though, is a non-religious number: an in-studio cover of Dionâ€™s â€œAbraham, Martin & John,â€ performed here as a heart-wrenching duet with singer Clydie King. Missing from the doc are the apocalyptic sermons Dylan would deliver onstage in 1979 and 1980; instead, we get actor Michael Shannon ominously intoning evangelical homilies in an atmospherically lit church. An odd touch, but it works, giving  a richer context.As was the case for many of his peers, things got weird for Dylan in the 1980s. Weirdest of all was , the dismal 1987 film Bob co-starred in with Rupert Everett and Fiona Flanagan. But something good did come of the songwriterâ€™s part in this dudâ€”namely, the BBCâ€™s , one of the most revealing and interesting Dylan portraits ever made. Its 50+ minutes are dominated by a tetchy interview filmed between  takes, with a wired Bob in full  mode. He gives interviewer Christopher Sykes an extremely hard time, refusing to give easy answers (or any real answers at all). â€œListen, Iâ€™ve come through good times and bad times, you know?â€ he says, glaring at his interrogator through wired eyes. â€œSo Iâ€™m not fooled by good times or bad times.â€ Itâ€™s riveting stuffâ€”and shows that Dylan had plenty of fire left in him at this career low point. The end of the doc is worth the price of admission alone, with Dylan chatting outside of his trailer with some pre-teen metalheads (who might not even know who theyâ€™re talking to). â€œYou guys like Ozzy?â€ Bob asks, suddenly morphing into a friendly uncle. â€œHow â€™bout Ratt?â€

Article: â€œAnd so this is our duty at every moment. To love without compromise and without equivocation.â€Yesterday (June 12), was Loving Day, a commemoration of the 1967 Supreme Court decision Loving v. Virginia, which struck down laws banning interracial marriage. To celebrate, Sufjan Stevens has penned an essay about love. He begins the essay with quotes from RuPaul (â€œIf you canâ€™t love yourself, how the hell you gonna love somebody else?â€) and Jesus (â€œLove your neighbor as yourselfâ€).Later, invoking Adam and Eve, he discusses shame: â€œItâ€™s astounding how much of our world still continues to teach us to feel shame,â€ he writes. â€œFor the color of our skin. For our poverty. For our wealth. For our education. For our religion. For our privilege. For our special need. For our sexuality. For being naked in a garden.â€Sufjan then offers love as the way to â€œbreak this patternâ€ of shame: â€œWe must go back to the beginning. We must be born again. We must be, and know, and love ourselves.â€ Read the full essay at Sufjanâ€™s website.Sufjan Stevens recently shared the songs â€œLove Yourselfâ€ and â€œWith My Whole Heartâ€ for Pride Month.

The track, performed as the fictional character Ashley O, includes lyrics adapted from Nine Inch Nailsâ€™ â€œHead Like a Holeâ€Netflix has shared the music video for â€œOn a Roll,â€ the song performed by Miley Cyrus (as Ashley O) in the â€œBlack Mirrorâ€ episode â€œRachel, Jack and Ashley Too.â€ Excerpts from the video were found in the episode. Watch below.â€œOn a Rollâ€ includes lyrics adapted from Nine Inch Nailsâ€™ â€œHead Like a Holeâ€: â€œHey there, whoah-ho, Iâ€™m on a roll/Riding so high, achieving my goals/ Iâ€™m so stoked on ambition and verve/Iâ€™m gonna get what I deserve.â€ Trent Reznor approved the adaptations and even released a t-shirt to commemorate the collaboration.Find â€œThe Miley Cyrus â€˜Black Mirrorâ€™ Episode Makes a Tired Argument About Popâ€ on the Pitch.

Listen to the track belowAs Black Belt Eagle Scout, Katherine Paul often draws on her childhood growing up in the Swinomish Indian Tribal Communityâ€”roots that hold deep meaning in the now Portland-based singer-songwriterâ€™s music. Paul has said that her upbringing on a reservation has manifested into a sense of apprehension about society; her new single, â€œAt the Party,â€ finds a slice of solace in navigating the human experience with similarly marginalized friends by her side. Here, â€œthe partyâ€ is the crooked world Paul journeys in solidarity with her fellow POC; together, they make the best of lifeâ€™s wayward turns.Waltzing drums propel the track, echoing like rolling thunder. â€œHow is it youâ€™ve suffered through this kind of love?/It puts you in a dark place, dark place,â€ Paul sings, her lyrics painting a corresponding cloudiness. Her hums sink into the mellow, winding instrumentation, creating a sonic palette thatâ€™s more funereal than festive. Even under such a shadow, â€œAt the Partyâ€ holds up the light of communal persistence: â€œWe will always sing,â€ she repeats, as the song ascends to a weightless outro. â€œIâ€™ll think of you from a nice, nice place,â€ goes the final lyric, insisting that, come any storm, Paulâ€™s friendships will serve as shelter.

He will reportedly pay $150,000 to end the legal battle that began the week he was fired as director of the Queen filmBryan Singer, the ousted director of , has agreed to pay $150,000 to settle a lawsuit focused on allegations of sexual assault,  reports. Cesar Sanchez-Guzman sued Singer in December 2017, alleging that the director sexually assaulted him during a yacht party in 2003. Sanchez-Guzman was 17 at the time of the alleged incident.Sanchez-Guzman filed for bankruptcy in 2014, and in 2018, his lawsuit against Singer was listed as a potential asset. A bankruptcy trustee reached a settlement agreement with Singerâ€™s attorneys and asked the court to approve a $150,000 settlement with Singer. Pending the settlementâ€™s approval, the lawsuit will be dismissed with prejudice.Singerâ€™s attorney Andrew Brettler released a statement about the settlement (via ). â€œThe debtor filed a claim against Mr. Singer that he had no basis or legal right to file,â€ he wrote. â€œMr. Singer has denied even knowing this individual, let alone allegedly having interacted with him more than 15 years ago. The decision to resolve the matter with the bankruptcy trustee was purely a business one, as litigation costs would well exceed the amount requested by the trustee to pay off the creditors who were owed money when the debtor filed for bankruptcy.â€The lawsuit was filed the same week Singer was fired as director of , reportedly due to his multiple absences on set during filming. In January,  published an investigative report where four men accused Singer of the sexual assault of minors.The 2019 GLAAD Media Awards withdrew â€™s nomination because of the allegations levied against Singer. Queenâ€™s Brian May issued an apology for saying Singer â€œis innocent until proven guilty.â€The filmâ€™s star Rami Malek, who won an Oscar for his performance as Freddie Mercury, addressed the allegations against Singer in an interview. â€œMy heart goes out to anyone who has to live through anything like what I've heard and what is out there. It's awful, it's remarkable that this happens, I can appreciate so much what they've been through and how difficult this must be for them,â€ he said. â€œIn the light of the Me Too era, that this somehow seems to exist after that, it's a horrible thing.â€
Showing: Read the Review

Article:
The move comes after Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp signed a near-total ban on abortion into lawOn May 7, Georgia became one of multiple states to pass a so-called â€œheartbeat bill.â€ The law bans abortions as early as six weeks into a pregnancy (before many women know theyâ€™re pregnant). Instead of boycotting performances in the state in protest of the new law (as many entertainers have done), Ariana Grande performed in Atlanta on June 8. She then donated a portion of the proceeds from her â€œSweetener World Tourâ€ performance to Planned Parenthood Federation of America, TMZ and People report. She donated $250,000, according to the reports.Dr. Leana Wen, President/CEO of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America and the Planned Parenthood Action Fund, shared the following statement:Ariana Grandeâ€™s generous donation comes at a critical timeâ€”in Georgia
and across the country, anti-womenâ€™s health politicians are trying to
ban all safe, legal abortion. This is not what the American people
want, nor is it something theyâ€™ll stand for. Thanks to inspiring
support like hers, Planned Parenthood can continue to fight backâ€”in
the courts, in Congress, in state houses, and in the streetsâ€”against
these dangerous attacks on people's health and lives. We are so
grateful to Ariana for her longstanding commitment to supporting
womenâ€™s rights and standing with Planned Parenthood to defend access
to reproductive health care. We wonâ€™t stop fightingâ€”no matter what.

Karen McCullah and Kiwi Smith are writing the screenplay.Read the Sunday Review of the Spice Girlsâ€™ 1996 debut Spice.

On Tuesday morning, Radiohead released around 16 hours of  outtakes on Bandcamp, with the proceeds going to fight the climate crisis. This might have seemed strange to those not obsessively following the group, but Radioheadâ€™s hand was essentially forced: The archival materialâ€”which includes long-sought alternate versions of â€œLiftâ€ and â€œTrue Love Waits,â€ solo demos, and other sonic experimentsâ€”leaked online last week. How did this treasure trove of music, made more than 20 years ago by one of the most critically acclaimed bands of all time, find its way to the internet now? It involves a black-market rap leaker being outmaneuvered by one of the internetâ€™s most active musical fanbases.It all began a few weeks ago, on May 26, when a user called Zimbra joined a Radiohead-oriented group on the chat app Discord, known as W.A.S.T.E. Central (yes, just like Radioheadâ€™s official social network). Though this personâ€™s entire presence in the Discord group has since been deleted, the initial responses to their comments make clear that Zimbra had access to and was teasing unreleased material from . When the album was given a 20th-anniversary reissue in 2017 (subtitled ), the box set included an exclusive cassette of demos and outtakes. Zimbra, whose handle echoes a classic Talking Heads song, seemed to have more where those came from.A little more than a week later, on June 3, a post on Redditâ€™s Radiohead channel sounded the alarm: A well-known leaker claimed to have 18 hours of tracks made by Thom Yorke during the recording of . Though the post didnâ€™t mention Zimbra by name, the leaker had shared previews of the kinds of material first teased by Zimbra, reportedly asking $150,000 for the full stash, or $800 per studio track and $50 per live track. A dubiously sourced archive documenting the making of a momentous albumâ€”a fanâ€™s holy grail, an artistâ€™s private rough drafts, and a copyright lawyerâ€™s worst nightmareâ€”was effectively being held for â€œransom,â€ as Jonny Greenwood later put it.On June 4, a user named Hoserama joined the Radiohead Discord chat. While Hoserama is the handle of a concert taper and trader whoâ€™s well known in online Radiohead circles, evidence later emerged that this user was not the longstanding Hoserama, but rather Zimbra pretending to be Hoserama. (â€œWhat if I make a Discord with that username. And then leak the entire thing as him?â€ a screenshot of an apparent chat log with Zimbra reads.) â€œTold you Iâ€™d be back,â€ this fake Hoserama posted last week, along with a link to a site hosting a 1.38-gigabyte cache of the outtakes in questionâ€”more than 17 hoursâ€™ worth. â€œMore soon,â€ he promised, before quitting the group.The leak spread quickly. Amid much hand-wringing over hearing tracks that were never intended for public consumption, the Radiohead fan community began compiling a Google doc that outlines the contents of these 18 lengthy audio files. John Nicholas, the Google docâ€™s owner, is candid with me about the moral quandary of a leak that is not sanctioned by the artist. â€œIn the situation we were placed in, it seemed that we were approaching something on the level of the  tapes or perhaps even , considering how many unreleased Thom solo demos were in this particular set,â€ he writes via email. â€œIt made more sense to convince the leaker to share something of that magnitude without making a profit off the bandâ€™s work, which would have been the outcome had we not gone public with the leakerâ€™s info.â€ The fansâ€™ Reddit post, in other words, forced the leakerâ€™s hand.Zimbra, who is prominent on the rap-leak forum Leakth.is, claims to have acquired the  sessions through the Leakth.is Discord group. â€œI advertised I had some unreleased Beatles,â€ Zimbra tells me via Discord direct message. â€œSo I get a DM from a Hoserama account saying he has 18 hours of unreleased Radioheadâ€¦ Google the username and of course I find the whole thing about him and concerts and so on. I figure well, this guy seems legit, he has snippets and everything which verify itâ€™s really unreleased. I trade him after an hour of banter trying to learn how he got it.â€Back on Leakth.is, Zimbra apparently offered one of the newly obtained versions of â€œLiftâ€ for $500. â€œConsidering that Kanye mumbling for 2 minutes sells for about $2K, I think thatâ€™s a pretty good deal right?â€ Zimbra tells me. â€œTurns out itâ€™s not.â€ Direct messages start arriving consisting of â€œpeople just massively hating on me, some asking how much for all 18 hoursâ€¦ I toss the $150K figure to someone as a hypothetical because at some point you can just do the math... Then the Reddit post drops and at this point everyone kinda freaks out. I do, the now-known-false Hoserama account does, Reddit does too. And it leaks.â€The actual Hoserama, whom I reach through several online accounts, denies taking part in the leak. â€œIâ€™m not the guy who released the  sessions,â€ Hoserama says through the Radiohead Discord group, which he only joined after hearing about the drama. â€œItâ€™s some guy, no idea who, who basically took my name.â€ Later over email Hoserama reiterates, â€œI had nothing to do with the Radiohead sessions.â€John Nicholas, the Google doc guy, says the Reddit post helped shame Zimbra into posing as the more established Radiohead bootlegger and leaking the same files they had been trying to sell, just hours before. â€œI donâ€™t get the sense that Zimbra is the actual thief, but none of his stories about how he obtained the files really add up either,â€ Nicholas writes. â€œIn the end, he was so spooked by the chance of being outed beyond the private, Martin Shkreli-like trading circles that he briefly impersonated Hoserama.â€For their part, Zimbra declines to comment on the record about who posted the leak. When it comes to Radioheadâ€™s official release of it, Zimbra seems ambivalent. â€œTheir response is for sure a very Radiohead-ish response,â€ Zimbra tells me via a secure email account. â€œEven my anxiety is giving me a confused look trying to figure out if this is good or bad. Sucks the whole $150k thing and â€˜ransomâ€™ was taken way out of context to the point of the band saying it, but oh well.â€Nicholas, from the Google doc, actually concurs on this point. â€œApparently the band is under the impression that they were being extorted by the original leaker,â€ he writes. â€œI donâ€™t think that was Zimbraâ€™s intent. While weâ€™re not a fan of what Zimbra was trying to do, at all, he never told us anything to suggest he was trying to get money from the band, only from fans.â€For now, who might have traded the  leak to Zimbra in the first place remains a mystery. â€œIâ€™m pretty much as in the dark as you,â€ Zimbra writes to me. â€œThe fake Hoserama is who I got it from initially. I tried to contact them afterwardsâ€¦ even tried to figure out myself who it was. But stuff like this happens. People will make alternate accounts to sell one specific thing if itâ€™s too risky. Iâ€™d say thatâ€™s the case here.â€Unsurprisingly, Nicholas has a theory about this as well. â€œThe situation that makes the most sense to me is that these minidiscs were digitized by a third party so the band could choose material from them for the  box set, and that someone involved at the third party stole the files and traded them,â€ he says, but notes that Zimbra also mentioned having other Radiohead music that was not part of the leak. â€œItâ€™s possible that there was a larger theft at work here.â€This time, hyper-vigilant fansâ€”and Radiohead themselvesâ€”appear to have made the best of a strange situation, transforming a leakerâ€™s personal profit motive into charitable support for Extinction Rebellion: an environmental activist group that wants to save the physical world.

The company says the bombshell story contains â€œinaccuracies, misleading statements, contradictions and fundamental misunderstandingsâ€After â€™ bombshell story on a 2008 warehouse blaze that reportedly destroyed scores of classic master tapes, Universal Music Group has released a statement playing down the extent of the damage. The fire at Universal Studios Hollywood reportedly destroyed a priceless trove of master tapes, affecting artists including Nirvana, R.E.M., John Coltrane, Joni Mitchell, and Aretha Franklin, among many others, according to .In response, UMG wrote in a statement that, â€œwhile there are constraints preventing us from publicly addressing some of the details,â€ the incident â€œnever affected the availability of the commercially released music nor impacted artistsâ€™ compensation.â€ They claim â€™ story â€œcontains numerous inaccuracies, misleading statements, contradictions and fundamental misunderstandings of the scope of the incident and affected assets.â€ UMG provided no examples of inaccuracies, and, at the time of publication, the labelâ€™s spokesperson has not returned a request for elaboration.The statement adds that â€™ article â€œconveniently ignores the tens of thousands of back catalog recordings that we have already issued in recent yearsâ€”including master-quality, high-resolution, audiophile versions of many recordings that the story claims were â€˜destroyed.â€™â€ It is unclear whether Universal denies certain master tapes were incinerated, or if the company simply believes reproductions have been made to â€œmaster-quality.â€ Pitchfork has emailed for further clarification.UMG goes on to say that, in the past five years, it has more than doubled â€œinvestment in storage, preservation and metadata enrichment,â€ as well as moving to support its â€œglobal efforts around capturing, preserving and future-proofing our many media assets.â€In an internal memo to employees published by , Universal Music Group CEO Sir Lucian Grange wrote about the â€œheartbreakingâ€ loss of archived material in the fire. â€œLet me be clear: we owe our artists transparency,â€ he wrote. â€œWe owe them answers. I will ensure that the senior management of this company, starting with me, owns this.â€According to , a Los Angeles law firm representing several UMG artists has sent a letter to Grange requesting a â€œcomplete inventory of all master recordings.â€Yesterday (June 11), Questlove suggested on Twitter that the fire destroyed the possibility of reissues for classic Roots albums  and . In addition, Hole said that Universal never told them that recordings were destroyed.

15 poets from Chicagoâ€™s youth poetry festival will perform their work in between sets at the Blue StagePitchfork is happy to announce that Young Chicago Authorsâ€™ Louder Than A Bomb Poets will perform at this yearâ€™s Pitchfork Music Festival. DistroLock will allow artists to pre-register songs before theyâ€™re released or submitted to streaming servicesMusic distribution company DistroKid has announced DistroLock, a new web-based service that allows artists to upload their unreleased music to a database that is used to prevent the release of â€œleakedâ€ content unofficially onto streaming services and other platforms. Developed in partnership with digital content identification company Audible Magic, the DistroLock program will generate a unique â€œaudio fingerprintâ€ for any song and add that fingerprint to the Audible Magic database, which currently contains â€œover 20 million media assets,â€ according to a press release.â€œUntil now, there hasnâ€™t been a definitive way for artists to say, â€˜This is my audio, donâ€™t let anyone else release it,â€™â€ DistroKid CEO Philip Kaplan said in a statement. â€œWith the launch of DistroLock, any musician can preemptively register their audio to help ensure that unauthorized releases donâ€™t see the light of day.â€DistroLock is making its API freely available to any music distributors, streaming services, and social media networks that wish to integrate a validation protocol within their content chain in order to fight the proliferation of such fraudulent releases in the future. In addition to registering songs within the Audible Magic database, DistroLock gives users the ability to register their content with other detection services like the open-source AcoustID and YouTube Content ID.As part of the partnership between the two companies, all tracks uploaded to DistroKid will now be analyzed via Audible Magicâ€™s RightsRx service, which cross-references the songs against the Audible Magic database. (In the past several months, Audible Magic has entered into similar partnerships with two other distribution companies, The Orchard and CDBaby.)In recent months, demos and other musical detritus from SZA, BeyoncÃ©, Rihanna, and Playboi Carti have been uploaded to streaming services. In some cases, the fraudulent music has performed well on charts: The Rihanna hoax album (Fenty Fantasiaâ€™s ) hit No. 67 on iTunesâ€™ worldwide albums chart; and the Carti leak (â€œKid Cartiâ€ by Lil Kambo) briefly topped the U.S. Viral 50 chart on Spotify.The fraudulent â€œKid Cartiâ€ was distributed onto Spotify via DistroKid. Spotify owns a minority stake in DistroKid.Read â€œWhoâ€™s Going to Stop Spotifyâ€™s Viral Rap Impersonators?â€ on the Pitch.

It features Jenny Lewis, Phil Cook, and more. In a statement, M.C. Taylor called the songs â€œmy therapy and my church.â€I realized that maybe these songs were good for something after all,

and brighter and not so dire. And through the songs ran a lineâ€”the

Earlier today, Radiohead released over 16 hours of unheard demos, rehearsals, outtakes, live performances, and other miscellany recorded around the time they were working on 1997â€™s . According to a statement from guitarist Jonny Greenwood, the band never wanted to put these recordings out, but once they realized someone had stolen a cache of MiniDiscs from Thom Yorkeâ€™s archiveâ€”and was reportedly demanding $150,000 to not release themâ€”they decided to upload everything onto Bandcamp themselves. You can stream it all for free for the next 18 days only, or pay Â£18 for downloads, with the proceeds going to the environmental organization Extinction Rebellion. â€œSo for Â£18 you can find out if we should have paid that ransom,â€ Greenwood quipped. For his part, Yorke wrote in the Bandcamp releaseâ€™s description: â€œitâ€™s not v interesting. thereâ€™s a lot of it.â€Heâ€™s not completely wrong: Contextless recordings put out under duress in an unwieldy and unabridged format do not make for an ideal listening experience. Nevertheless, here we are. Vast swaths of this materialâ€”underdeveloped early drafts, eerie found sounds, random jamsâ€”would likely be notable to only the most diehard Radiohead fans (several of which have already created an annotated guide to the whole thing). And yet, there are a few moments of brilliance (and strangeness) that cut through: an alternate version of fan favorite â€œLiftâ€ that could have topped the charts, a whole EPâ€™s worth of Yorke singing unreleased songs with his acoustic guitar, a 12-minute take of â€œParanoid Android.â€ Thereâ€™s even one part where Yorke starts beatboxing. Hereâ€™s a selection of highlights, rarities, and oddities that we were drawn to most. (Special thanks to writer Matthew Perpetua for mapping out some of these gems before we did.)The fabled â€œLiftâ€â€”the song Radiohead chose not to release as the first single from  because it would have made them â€œtoo big,â€ the song with a story longer than this leakâ€”was finally heard in studio-recorded form on 2017â€™s 20th-anniversary reissue, . This alternate version is even better. Itâ€™s not mixed very carefully, but it sounds scrappy and untamed, like the band is pushing it into the red unselfconsciously. It lives up to the myth. â€“Jeremy D. LarsonNormally, combing through a bandâ€™s alternate takes feels like settling on one of seven nearly-identical selfies. But Radioheadâ€™s alternate takes are more like alternate conceptionsâ€”different lives the songs might have lived. Hearing the full-band version of â€œMotion Picture Soundtrack,â€ without the lush Bond-theme string arrangements that made it to the finished  studio version, is to see another Radiohead. The guitars chime, the cymbals splash quietly.  Radiohead never deviated from the path suggested by . Here, itâ€™s very nearly another â€œFake Plastic Trees.â€ â€“Jayson GreeneMost of the in-progress versions of â€œParanoid Androidâ€ that appear on the leak are either scraps of rehearsal starting from various parts of the song or live versions from 1996, when Radiohead opened for Alanis Morissette. But this version answers the question: â€œWhat if Radioheadâ€™s most expansive prog-rock opus was twice as long?â€ Itâ€™s rough and loose, with a few different lyrics. At one point, it descends into a kind of â€œDazed and Confusedâ€ psychedelic section with lots of clicks and clacks on the rims of drum heads. It feels like a jam session waiting for someone to end it. â€“JDLThis previously unreleased track is pure yearbook-photo material, equal parts embarrassingly awkward and sweet. A simple, near-Britpop strummer, it sounds very nearly like Del Amitriâ€™s inescapable 1995 hit â€œRoll to Me,â€ slowed down to half-tempo. Polished up in a studio, it could have soundtracked a late-â€™90s teen comedy, and you wouldnâ€™t have blinked. â€“JGListening to these tapes, youâ€™ll come across something that has the scuzzy fidelity of an early Mountain Goats tape or an old 78. There are two versions of â€™ â€œNudeâ€ to be found hereâ€”a full band take and this extremely lo-fi acoustic demo from Yorke that almost feels like someone trying to creepily cover it. This early draft is spectral and difficult to make out, but therein lies its allure: It allows you to trace its journey from this demo to the song we know. â€“JDLWell, this doesnâ€™t really work, does it! Perhaps there is just too much lore around this song, which only existed as a cherished live bootleg for decades until a meditative version finally arrived on Radioheadâ€™s latest album, . This early take pulls the song into an uncomfortable shape thanks to some spacey ELO synths and a regrettable wah-wah effect. It offers insight into why one of Radioheadâ€™s most pure and uncynical songs was notoriously difficult to pin down. â€“JDLThis version removes the big old Tommy Iommi-style riff as well as the DJ Shadow-influenced stuttering beat from the center of â€™s monolithic opener, and lo and behold, it becomes airy, sweet, nearly weightlessâ€”something an alternate-universe Radiohead could have performed on another MTV Spring Break. â€“JGThe version released on  features some of the best, simplest guitar arrangements Radiohead ever put to tape, an interwoven chime that makes it sounds like you are inside the bells of a church. If you never wanted those guitar notes to stop bubbling over, here is a 10-minute version of that. â€“JDLAs the closer to , the studio version of â€œLife in a Glasshouseâ€ brimmed with near-apocalyptic intensity, Yorkeâ€™s voice mingling with the scream of New Orleans-style brass and woodwinds. This demo is a skeleton, just a hard-strummed acoustic and Yorkeâ€™s holler; the energy isnâ€™t too far off from something like KT Tunstallâ€™s 2004 hit â€œBlack Horse and a Cherry Tree.â€ â€“JGThe solo Thom Yorke cuts sprinkled throughout the leak are winningly pure-hearted and lovely, in the simplest sense of the word. This song, which begins with Yorke yelping out a strangled â€œMaybe this is not the reason,â€ finds the singer exploring his pinched, pained upper reaches, where his chest voice breaks into falsetto. There is a hiccup in the tape somewhere in the middle, but even with that glitch, the song is a hauntingly indelible wail. â€“JGThere is a lost solo coffeehouse EP somewhere in this data dump, which Yorke might want to keep buried, but these humble takes showcase the larger-than-life frontman at his most vulnerable. The melodies to several Yorke solo demos from the leak didnâ€™t seem to find homes in other Radiohead songs, perhaps because they were not dark enough, or maybe they didnâ€™t lend themselves readily to full-band arrangements. (Or, knowing the pace at which Radiohead works on songs, perhaps they are still in development somewhere in the bandâ€™s collective unconscious.) â€“JG

For most of the recordings on , a new Prince compilation featuring solo demos of songs written for other artists, the only other person in the room was Peggy McCreary. As Princeâ€™s trusted audio engineer at Los Angelesâ€™ Sunset Sound studio starting with 1981â€™s Controversy all the way through 1986â€™s , McCreary worked closely on the records that initially defined his career. This was Princeâ€™s most prolific time period: In addition to his own five albums, he mentored acts including Vanity 6 and Sheila E. and wrote standalone hits like the Banglesâ€™ â€œManic Mondayâ€ and â€œNothing Compares 2 U,â€ later SinÃ©ad Oâ€™Connorâ€™s signature song. It was also the era when Prince became a superstar. McCreary witnessed his transformation up close, one painstaking session at a time. â€œHe told me once that the only reason he went home was because he knew I needed to sleep,â€ she recalls.Working with Princeâ€”whose high maintenance, technophobic intensity still seems to summon an anxious tug in McCrearyâ€™s voiceâ€”was no easy feat. â€œI appreciated him a lot more when I wasn't working with him,â€ she jokes now. Like every frequent Prince collaborator, McCreary has great stories. Even though she says those endless hours in the studio rendered her memory foggy, she remembers him deciding at midnight that â€œPurple Rainâ€ needed a string section, and how she taught him to use a mixing board so she could watch â€œDallasâ€ in the break room every once in a while. And if it werenâ€™t for Prince, she might still be a smoker: He demanded she quit so that sheâ€™d stop taking breaks in the middle of their sessions.During our conversation, McCreary gave insight into the man behind all those recordingsâ€”a perfectionist whose constant drive to create left us with a body of work thatâ€™s still being uncovered and understood. , the latest posthumous release from Princeâ€™s vault, is available on Tidal now and hits other streaming services on June 21; a physical release is due July 19.Peggy McCreary: I was a waitress at the Roxy Theatre on the Sunset Strip. I worked there for two years and I thought,  I really liked working around music, so I started taking classes, something called Sound Masters, and helping the sound men set up during the day. One time, [one of the sound guys] said to me, â€œIf youâ€™re serious about doing this, they are looking for a gopher at Sunset Sound.â€ So I went down and applied. They had never hired a woman before, and I think they hired me as a joke, thinking itâ€™d be funny. But then I had good studio etiquette. I knew when to keep my mouth shut. I worked hard. I absorbed everything and helped every way that I could.Hollywood Sound [a nearby studio] had technical difficulties and their board went down. They called Sunset and said, â€œDo you have an engineer and a room available this weekend?â€ And I was available with a room, but the receptionist said, â€œPeggy canâ€™t work alone in the studio on the weekend with him. He writes really dirty songs about giving head and stuff.â€ I thought,  So I was prepared for something different than the person that walked in, who was small and polite and extremely quiet. He would mumble what he needed from behind a flap of hair. I said, â€œYou know what? If you want me to work with you, youâ€™re going to have to talk to me, to my face, so I can hear you!â€ That was on , and we finished that album, and I thought, . But when he came back for 1999, he requested me. So I guess we did connect in some way. But he wasnâ€™t real communicative, and he wasnâ€™t very cordial. He didnâ€™t have those basics that most people haveâ€”hello and goodbye and thank you.It was half and half. Sometimes heâ€™d come with lyrics written on the hotel stationary. Sometimes he would sit at the piano and write on the back of track sheets or a napkin or whatever there was. I remember with â€œManic Monday,â€ we had worked until about 5 or 6 in the morning, and he said, â€œOkay, weâ€™ll be in at 6 tomorrow evening.â€ And I thought, . I got a call from the studio the next morning that he wanted to be in at noon. I wasnâ€™t real happy when he walked in, but he had this big smile on his face and he waved some lyric sheets in front of me and said, â€œI said if I dreamed another verse I was coming in!â€ He was constantly composing, no matter where he was or what he was doing.I just think itâ€™s where the song took him. I remember when we first did â€œWhen Doves Cry,â€ I didnâ€™t pay much attention to it. It seemed like a big grandiose, overproduced thing. And when I listened to the original one, I see why. We came back the next day and he basically unproduced itâ€”took out all the synths and the screaming guitars. The very last thing he did was take out the bass. He just looked at me and said, â€œAinâ€™t nobody going to believe I do this.â€ And it was a huge hit!He became different, yeah. There was a lot of pressure, especially for a 25-year-old kid. He had the last say over everything. But did he treat me differently? He always was Prince. I remember after , which was just me and him in the studio, we were working on Vanity 6, I think. I said, â€œDo you like my work?â€ And he looked at me like, â€œYouâ€™re here, arenâ€™t you?â€ Thatâ€™s all you ever got from him.I remember one day the Time came in, it was a shitty day. It didn't have anything to do with me, but I seemed to be the scapegoat. When Prince came in, I knew it was going to be a bad day by the way he was walking and how he was dressed. He had high-heeled boots, no shirtâ€”which was very rareâ€”a bandana tied around his head, and one around each knee. He was just strutting... and it was an  strut. I guess somebody had lost a tape and he was furious. So he came in, and he just rode me so hard. He was bitching about how white people didnâ€™t have any rhythmâ€”and itâ€™s like, oh my god really? Your drummer is white! I remember looking over at Jimmy Jam [then a member of the Time] and he was looking at me like, â€œIâ€™m so sorry itâ€™s you, but Iâ€™m so glad itâ€™s not me!â€I think he was more comfortable around women in general. I think thatâ€™s why he surrounded himself with women. Women donâ€™t have the same male ego conflict kind of thing. You just did what he needed you to do.Being a woman in the studio then, you either got a lot of hatredâ€”that you shouldnâ€™t be thereâ€”or a lot of unwanted attention, which you had to manage by not offending. And he was justâ€¦ You were an equal. I didnâ€™t ever feel objectified by him.Iâ€™m sure he would have an opinion! I donâ€™t think he would have appreciated his song being in a commercial. But heâ€™s not here. He should have left a will of what he wanted.He came in one time on my birthday. I was like,  You could always hear him walking through the courtyard because he had those high-heeled boots and he had a certain way of walking. But he was dressed totally different than I had ever seen him: black leather boots, jeansâ€”which he never woreâ€”white t-shirt, and a black leather jacket. We cut a rockabilly song all day long. So we finished up, and I made him a cassette and handed it to him. And he stood there at the door with a little smile on his face and threw the cassette at me and said, â€œHappy birthday.â€ And that was my birthday song. I have an unreleased Prince song. To him, that was probably the greatest gift he could have given meâ€”a day in the studio!It was the â€™80s, so it was a time of excess. I watched people agonize over a snare sound for days: tune it, change it, this and that. You would spend weeks on tracks, and then youâ€™d spend weeks on overdubs, and then weeks on mixing. He was so different than anybody I ever worked with. Technically Iâ€™m not real proud of some of our stuff, because I didnâ€™t have time. I couldnâ€™t â€œblow the groove.â€ Heâ€™d say, â€œPeggy, youâ€™re blowing the groove! Come on, letâ€™s get going!â€ But what happened is, I got tired of focusing on things that didnâ€™t matter. I was like, . [Prince] would just work from start to finish. I always felt his music was really fresh. If the musicâ€™s good, it doesnâ€™t really matter.

The Roots, R.E.M., and Steely Dan also reacted to losing master tapes in a 2008 blaze at Universal Studios HollywoodToday, a  investigation revealed that a blaze at Universal Studios Hollywood in 2008 destroyed an enormous number of master tapes by artists throughout the decades, including Nirvana, Eminem, John Coltrane, and many more.Hole were among the artists who lost master recordings in the incident. After being contacted by Pitchfork, the bandâ€™s representative confirmed that Hole was never made told by Universal that their tapes were destroyed. The band was â€œnot aware until this morning,â€ states the rep.Another band who lost their recordings in the fire, R.E.M., took to Twitter to address the news. â€œREMHQ is receiving inquiries from many people concerned about the New York Times article on the Universal Music fire 11 years ago,â€ the band wrote. â€œWe are trying to get good information to find out what happened and the effect on the bandâ€™s music, if any. We will detail further as and when.â€Questlove also commented on the revelation that the Roots lost recordings in the fire. He shared the link to the  report, adding, â€œFor everyone asking why  &  wont get reissue treatment.â€ He added, â€œI been dying to find all the old reels and mix the 8 or 9 songs that never made DYWM. My plan for both DYWM & IH was to release all the songs and instrumental/acapella mixes on 45.â€Steely Danâ€™s manager Irving Azoff released a statement on behalf of the band. "We have been aware of â€˜missingâ€™ original Steely Dan tapes for a long time now,â€ he wrote. â€œWeâ€™ve never been given a plausible explanation. Maybe they burned up in the big fire. In any case, itâ€™s certainly a lost treasure.â€https://twitter.com/remhq/status/1138532624006295556?s=20

Acknowledging the eventâ€™s controversial history, the White Sox pledge that they are â€œdedicated to advocating for a safe, welcoming ballpark experience for all people and communitiesâ€This Thursday (June 13), the Chicago White Sox are giving away 10,000 t-shirts to commemorate the 40th anniversary of Disco Demolition Night, Chicago journalist Robert Feder notes. Written on the t-shirt is: â€œThe Night That Records Were Broken.â€ The shirt is available as part of the teamâ€™s Free T-Shirt Thursdays promotion. According to Feder, Steve Dahl, the radio jockey who stirred up anti-disco sentiment by destroying records, will throw out the gameâ€™s honorary first pitch.On July 12, 1979, station reps for Chicagoâ€™s WLUP and the White Sox teamed up to host Disco Demolition Night, a promotional event that offered 98-cent admission to a doubleheader for anybody who brought a disco record. Dahl was appointed to blow up all the records in centerfield at Comiskey Park between games. Once he did, fans rioted and charged the field.Musicians from the era have condemned the event. â€œIt felt to us like Nazi book-burning,â€ Nile Rodgers has said. â€œThis is America, the home of jazz and rock and people were now afraid even to say the word â€˜disco.â€™ I remember thinkingâ€”weâ€™re not even a disco group.â€ NPR has written that Disco Demolition Night has come â€œto be seen as a not-so-subtle attack against discoâ€™s early adopters: blacks, Latinos and gay people.â€When contacted by Pitchfork, a representative for the Chicago White Sox sent the following statement:This yearâ€™s Disco Demolition T-Shirt giveaway was intended to
recognize the anniversary of a historic off-the-field moment that has
been connected to the organization over the past 40 years. It is a
recognizable part of Chicago baseball history. We recently were made
aware of comments criticizing the T-Shirt giveaway and are in the
process of reviewing feedback. We have been communicating with our
community partners who have raised concerns to make it clear that the
intent of this giveaway was only meant to mark the historical nature
of the night 40 years later. We have reinforced that the White Sox
organization is dedicated to advocating for a safe, welcoming ballpark
experience for all people and communities, and will continue to engage
in important, informative discussions with our fans and partners to
build toward positive change through sports. We remain proud of our
franchiseâ€™s longstanding record on advocating for inclusion and
diversity.Watch Pitchforkâ€™s â€œYearbook: A Snapshot of Chicago's Music Scene in 1979â€:

The fest returns, bigger than ever, to La Grande Halle de la Villette from October 31 to November 2Pitchfork is excited to announce Pitchfork Music Festival Paris 2019. This yearâ€™s festival takes place from October 31 to November 2 at La Grande Halle de la Villette in the 19th arrondissement, the home of Pitchfork Paris since 2011. Those artists will perform at La Petite Halle and Boris Vian auditoriumâ€”two new stages located next to and within the Grande Halle. The two larger stages will remain inside the main venue and feature the headlining acts. There will be after-parties featuring electronic live shows and DJ sets at the Trabendo each night in partnership with Red Bull Music.

The corner of Fulton Street and St. James Place is now known as Christopher Wallace WayNotorious B.I.G. officially has a street in his hometown Brooklyn named after him, CBS New York reports. Today, the city held a renaming ceremony for the corner of Fulton Street and St. James Place in Clinton Hill, which is now known as Christopher â€˜Notorious B.I.G.â€™ Wallace Way. Lilâ€™ Kim spoke during the ceremony in honor of the late rapper. Biggieâ€™s mother, New York City Council member Laurie Cumbo, rapper Lil Cease, and other friends, and fans were also at the ceremony.The renaming petition was approved by the Brooklyn Community Board and Mayor Bill De Blasio last November. Christopher â€˜Notorious B.I.G.â€™ Wallace Way arrives after years of efforts to rename the street; due to the violent nature of his music, the memoriam met resistance from the city.Read â€œ10 Great Rap Songs About Moneyâ€ on the Pitch.https://twitter.com/BET/status/1138213549514338304

â€œWeâ€™re releasing all 18 hours on Bandcamp in aid of Extinction Rebellion,â€ says Jonny Greenwood, after hackers demand â€œransomâ€ from bandRadiohead have released 18 hours of OK Computer sessions that recently leaked online. Listen below, and buy the sessions for Â£18 (about $23) on Bandcamp. Proceeds go to Extinction Rebellion, the nonviolent climate activist group that recently staged sweeping protests in London. The release will be available for 18 days. Read Jonny Greenwoodâ€™s statement below.Greenwood wrote:We got hacked last week - someone stole Thomâ€™s minidisk archive from
around the time of OK Computer, and reportedly demanded $150,000 on
threat of releasing it. So instead of complaining - much - or ignoring
it, weâ€™re releasing all 18 hours on Bandcamp in aid of Extinction
Rebellion. Just for the next 18 days. So for Â£18 you can find out if
we should have paid that ransom.Never intended for public consumption (though some clips did reach the
cassette in the OK Computer reissue) itâ€™s only tangentially
interesting. And very, very long. Not a phone download. Rainy out,
isnâ€™t it though?In 2017, Radiohead reissued the 1997 classic titled OKNOTOK in honor of its 20th anniversary. It featured three unreleased songs and the long-awaited fan favorite â€œLift,â€ as well as the bonus cassette Greenwood mentions above.

The show premieres on July 17 at 10 p.m. Eastern.The first trailer for the show has arrived, and it shows Danny in conversation with guests including A$AP Rocky, EL-P, Hannibal Buress, ScHoolboy Q, the Insane Clown Posse, â€œBroad Cityâ€â€™s Ilana Glazer, Gilbert Gottfried, Ron Funches, wrestling legend â€œHacksawâ€ Jim Duggan, and more. Plus RosalÃ­a, John Waters, Arca, JPEGMAFIA, Big Freedia, and others grill Frank about leaving Def Jam, his routines, and moreFrank Ocean answered questions about his life, process, and his views on a number of topics in a new interview with . Frank, who rarely gives interviews, answered questions from luminaries like RosalÃ­a, John Waters, Arca, Billy Porter, Janet Mock, JPEGMAFIA, Big Freedia, Rex Orange County, and more. It was Nile Rodgers who pressed him on the long-overdue vinyl release of Channel Orange. Itâ€™s coming â€œASAP,â€ Frank replied.JPEGMAFIA pressed Frank about releasing Blonde immediately after departing Def Jam. â€œHow did it feel fucking over a label like that,â€ he asked, adding, â€œOld white n***as do that to us all the time, but how did it feel giving them a taste of their own elixir? And what did you build in the video for Endless? Can I live in it?â€ Frank replied:Eyy, Peggy! You know, itâ€™s funny talking about it these days because I
couldnâ€™t really tell anybody anything for a couple of years. Couldnâ€™t
tell anyone at the label, obviously. But I also couldnâ€™t talk with
anyone at Apple because the industry is too small and it wouldâ€™ve
gotten back to the label for sure. So I kept it to myself and a few in
my circle.I carried my hard drives around with me when I travelled because I
used to not store anything online. Those drives became a physical
representation of the stakes. If the files had leaked, everything
would have worked out very differently for me. When August came around
and both projects were uploaded I felt the euphoria, yeah, but mostly
I just needed to sleep. I probably slept something like 15 hours. To
answer your second question, I built a 12-foot staircase with my
fucking bare hands some days before! Itâ€™s in my storage, you want it??Arca asked Frank, â€œAre there any similarities or differences between Frank and Christopher?â€ (Frankâ€™s real name is Christopher Breaux.) Frank responded: â€œChristopher is a triangle wave. Frank is a pulse wave. Iâ€™m a little synthesizer. Xo.â€Elsewhere, he told John Waters that he wishes he wrote Ryuichi Sakamotoâ€™s title song from , answered a question from RosalÃ­a about whether he feels that he â€œbelong[s] to this world and time,â€ fielded a question from Evian Christ about his favorite dinosaur, shrugged off Matt Oxâ€™s question about his pre-studio routines, told designer Ava Nirui about his penchant for Cinnamon Toast Crunch, and detailed to actress Amandla Stenberg why he takes a cold shower every morning.Read the full article at .Head to the Pitch to â€œMeet the People Who Made Hundreds Selling Frank Oceanâ€™s Midterms Merch.â€

Itâ€™s', 'Frank', 'Frank', 'John Waters', 'Ryuichi Sakamoto']

Article: Universal Studios fire also consumed John Coltrane, Eminem, Joni Mitchell, and Tupac mastersA blaze at Universal Studios Hollywood in 2008 destroyed scores of master tapes of classic albums and singles, a  investigation reveals. Masters of records by Universal artists throughout the decades, including Nirvana, R.E.M., John Coltrane, Joni Mitchell, Eminem, Aretha Franklin, Nine Inch Nails, Ray Charles, Tupac, Janet Jackson, Beck, Snoop Dogg, and many more, were lost, limiting the possibilities for high-quality reproductions and adaptations in the future.The fire made headlines at the time, but Universal shifted attention to the burned â€œKing Kongâ€ theme park attraction and more manageable losses of video content, in an operation described as a â€œtriumph of crisis managementâ€ by the articleâ€™s author, Jody Rosen. Some suggest the label feared backlash from artists and estates whose masters were destroyed, according to the . â€œLost in the fire was, undoubtedly, a huge musical heritage,â€ reads a 2009 internal assessment viewed by the . That includes â€œalmost allâ€Â of Buddy Hollyâ€™s masters, most of John Coltraneâ€™s Impulse Records releases, and singles such as Bill Haley and His Cometsâ€™ â€œRock Around the Clockâ€ and Etta Jamesâ€™ â€œAt Last.â€In response to the article, Universal Music Group claimed in a statement to Pitchfork that â€™ article contains â€œnumerous inaccuracies, misleading statements, contradictions and fundamental misunderstandings of the scope of the incident and affected assets.â€ The company claims, in recent years, to have released â€œmaster-quality, high-resolution, audiophile versions of many recordings that the story claims were â€˜destroyed.â€™â€Universal adds that it has more than doubled its investment in â€œstorage, preservation, and metadata enrichmentâ€ in the last five years. Pitchfork has requested clarification on which elements of â€™ reporting UMG considers inaccurate.Read Jody Rosenâ€™s full story.
Entities: ['John Coltrane', 'Joni Mitchell', 'Nirvana', 'R.E.M.', 'John Coltrane', 'Joni Mitchell', 'Aretha Franklin', 'Nine Inch Nails', 'Tupac', 'Beck', 'Buddy Holly', 'John Coltrane', 'Bill Haley']

Article: Half of the proceeds will go towards Tiny Changes, a charity launched in memory of late frontman Scott HutchisonFrightened Rabbit have teamed with Reverb to launch an auction for Tiny Changes, their mental health charity. Last year, the band started Tiny Changes in honor of their late frontman Scott Hutchison to raise awareness of a provide support for children and young peopleâ€™s mental health issues. For the auction, the band will be selling their gear, including Hutchisonâ€™s amp. Check out the Frightened Rabbit Tiny Changes Reverb Charity Auction here.Half the proceeds will go towards Tiny Changes. â€œWe felt that putting everything up for auction would give people an opportunity to get something from the band that they themselves can put to good use,â€ Frightened Rabbit drummer and Hutchisonâ€™s brother Grant said in a statement. â€œMental health was a cause that was very close to Scottâ€™s heart and one that he would be extremely proud to see his family and the band supporting.â€Last year, Ben Gibbard, Julien Baker, and more played a Scott Hutchison tribute concert that was later released as A Celebration of the Songs of Scott Hutchison.Read â€œWhy Losing Frightened Rabbitâ€™s Scott Hutchison Hurts So Muchâ€ on the Pitch.

After Watkins Glen International and CID Entertainment backed out, organizers insist that the event is still happeningWoodstock 50, a 50th anniversary event celebrating the iconic 1969 festival, was originally scheduled to take place from August 16-18 at an upstate New York racetrack called Watkins Glen International. But today, following a recent series of setbacks and complications, the festival has lost their venue. â€œWatkins Glen International terminated the site license for Woodstock pursuant to provisions of the contract,â€ the venue confirmed in a statement. â€œAs such, WGI will not be hosting the Woodstock 50 Festival.â€Less than an hour after the venue made the announcement, the festivalâ€™s producer CID Entertainment released a statement announcing that they were also cutting ties with Woodstock 50. â€œCID Entertainment had been engaged to provide enhanced camping, travel packages and transportation for Woodstock 50,â€ CID Entertainment head Dan Berkowitz said in a statement to . â€œGiven developments, we can confirm that CID is no longer involved in Woodstock 50 in any capacity.â€After Watkins Glen International backed out, Woodstock 50 LLC principal Gregory Peck claimed in a statement that the event will still happen. â€œWe are in discussions with another venue to host Woodstock 50 on August 16-18 and look forward to sharing the new location when tickets go on sale in the coming weeks,â€ he said. Pitchfork has reached out to Woodstock 50 about CID Entertainmentâ€™s announcement.The news follows a legal battle between Woodstock 50 and their former financial backers Dentsu Aegis Network, who pulled out of the festival in April and claimed the event was canceled. Since, Woodstock 50 has found new investors and assured the public that the festival is still on.Woodstock 50â€™s lineup, announced in March, was initially scheduled to feature JAY-Z, the Killers, Chance the Rapper, Miley Cyrus, and the Raconteurs, among others. In April, the Black Keys pulled out of the festival over a stated scheduling conflict. The festival never officially released tickets as reports of insufficient permits surfaced.Read Pitchforkâ€™s timeline of Woodstock 50â€™s ongoing hurdles.

These are the songs Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren, Beto Oâ€™Rourke, Kamala Harris, and more played at the Iowa Democratsâ€™ Hall of Fame dinnerYesterday (June 9), 19 Democratic presidential candidates gave speeches at the Iowa Democratsâ€™ Hall of Fame dinner. Before each of their speeches, a walkout song played, as  politics reporter Lissandra Villa notes. Among the notable selections were the Clashâ€™s â€œClampdownâ€ (Rep. Beto Oâ€™Rourke) and â€œRudie Canâ€™t Failâ€ (Bill de Blasio), as well as Lil Nas Xâ€™s â€œOld Town Roadâ€ (Rep. Tim Ryan). Plus, Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand picked Lizzoâ€™s â€œGood as Hell.â€ Below, check out all of the candidatesâ€™ selections (in order of appearance at the dinner). Scroll down for all of their speeches (via C-SPAN).Beto Oâ€™Rourke has shown love for the Clashâ€™s â€œClampdownâ€ in the past. Last year, when he was running for Senate against Ted Cruz, he referenced the song during a debate. Spoon then covered the song in Texas as a nod to Oâ€™Rourke.Last month, New York Mayor Bill de Blasio said, â€œMy favorite band is the Clashâ€ on CNN. He added, â€œI love reggae,â€ and, â€œI love ska.â€

Last yearâ€™s ruling that the 2016 copyright case will get a new trial will get a further look in appeals courtIn 2016, a judge ruled in favor of Led Zeppelin in a lawsuit from Michael Skidmore, a trustee for the estate of former Spirit guitarist Randy California. Skidmore claimed in his suit the intro of Zeppelinâ€™s 1971 classic â€œStairway to Heavenâ€ was improperly inspired by Spiritâ€™s 1968 instrumental â€œTaurus.â€ Last year, a three-judge panel of the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the previous judge had â€œprovided erroneous jury instructionsâ€ and that it would be headed back to court. Now, Led Zeppelin will get another stab at that ruling, as Law360 reporter Bill Donahue notes and Pitchfork confirms via court documents.It was decided today (June 10) that all members of the appellate court will rehear the case, as  notes. This means that itâ€™s possible that the 2016 ruling in Zeppelinâ€™s favor will remain intact, depending on the results of  hearings set to take place the week of September 23, 2019.
